It chose not to do so because, although it had the legislative capacity to do so because it had the full support of the Australian Democrats for quite radical programs, the programs were not feasible in the ultimate in light of public opinion and the constitutional, legal and other realities of Australia.

I do not think that the Minister is entitled at this stage of his career to be expressing immense pride. This document is a confession of failure and I believe that it is important that that be noted because there have been too many false starts in Aboriginal affairs. I would simply wish to express my sympathy with the Aboriginal people of Australia who, every time a new Minister or government appears on the scene, find they are faced with yet another wonderful new solution. What has been done before is suddenly superseded and they are expected to respond to the latest theory as to what will provide them with a decent and honourable place in Australian society. I also remind the Senate that although the ministerial statement purports to be doing something radical and new, there is already in Australia something called the Aboriginal Development Commission which was established in 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Minister?

—That was during my own Ministry. I thank Senator Baume. However, the point I want to make-I hope I will be able to do so at length later in my speech-is that a fully independent Aboriginal commission was established in 1980 after a most extensive process of consultation with the Aboriginal people. That process of consultation involved not only a representative of national organisations but also a team of public servants going out and talking in great detail with communities right round Australia. Again, I hope to go into that in a little more detail later but, as I said, we already have an Aboriginal Development Commission with a fully Aboriginal board. I make the point that the members of that board have been totally appointed by the present Government; all the appointees have been put on the board since the present Government came to office-except the present chairperson of that body who was appointed as chairperson by the present Government subsequent to her appointment to the board by the previous Liberal-National Party Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement represents a development in Aboriginal affairs with some limited good aspects. I will touch on those. However, the statement does have some very real negatives. It is important that the Opposition mark what those negatives are at the start of what is quite an important debate. Again, I draw attention to the `starting-again' syndrome-the fact that we have a new Minister who, seeing that the problem has not been solved in the past, is determined to make a fresh start. I simply remind the Government and the Senate that a continuous process of fresh starts is not really a formula for achieving progress.

I also think that the document-this is probably the most significant criticism which is to be made of the document-opens up issues which are more likely to cause problems and uncertainties than to create progress. I am sure that in the minds of Australian Labor Party people and, certainly, Labor Party members of parliament, there is some doubt when a Liberal or National Party member of parliament gets up and expresses concern in regard to the Labor Party's talking in terms of prior ownership, treaties, and all the rest of it. After all, is this not a wonderful, progressive, honest and just thing to be doing? I therefore want to take some words from an article in a newspaper which I do not think could be regarded as a right wing paper or a paper which automatically picks up the views of the Liberal Party of Australia. On this occasion I think it expresses in very moderate terms the concern which I certainly feel about the Government's approach. The leading article in the Canberra Times of last Monday referred to the fact that the Government has talked about the dispossession of land and its prior ownership. That article stated:

The words give comfort to the lobby which believes in a focus on compensation policies-but they convey no entitlement. In truth, many Aboriginal-Affairs policies are founded on an assumption of a duty of compensation, and there is nothing constitutional inhibiting the Commonwealth from directly embarking on formal compensation programs. But the very word, like `land rights' in the minds of some, attracts a political reaction, and a wise government is better focused on programs explicitly directed at improving the lot of Aboriginal Australians without setting out to use mere symbols which appease some consciences and salve some wounds without actually doing anything at all and which in fact attract opposition to Aboriginal advancement. The words thus, are perhaps a useful phrase-certainly they are no more than a statement of the obvious-but are no more than tokenism; it is the action which counts.

I think that is a very fair summary of what I might say in a more heated debate in a sharper fashion. Tokenism and the use of words which produce the warm inner glow are unlikely to produce progress for Aboriginal people in 1988 or at any other time. I believe that the Government should sit back and look very soberly at the impact of its embracing of fairly radical proposals in the past and the impact which that has had on Aboriginal people and on community attitudes to Aboriginal people. I believe that any honest assessment of that will demonstrate to the Government that what it has done has in fact worsened the lot of those it was seeking to help.

I do believe that it is incumbent on the Government to examine its conscience on the way it has tackled Aboriginal affairs. I remind it very briefly that what it did over the whole of its period in opposition was to make promises which it has subsequently found are impossible to keep. But the promises which it made, particularly the promises of overriding the States with respect to land, gave rise to Aboriginal expectations and demands, and those Aboriginal expectations and demands in turn caused a loss of sympathy for Aboriginal people and, of course, in the end the Government did not deliver.

It has been a cycle which I think is extremely damning of the Australian Labor Party and it is a cycle which I think the Government should be very reluctant to see commence again. In those circumstances I believe that the Government should be extremely cautious in talking about the immense pride that it feels in making this announcement and it certainly should be very cautious in assessing where it goes from here. The fact is that the ALP has destroyed support for Aboriginal advancement programs. I have spoken to many people, including many Labor sympathisers and supporters, and indeed people who are active in the Labor Party, who agree that the position of Aboriginal Australians has gone backwards over the last 10 years, and I think the Labor Party has been a substantial contributor to that and not least in the vital area of community attitudes.

There is in fact an extraordinary disillusion in the community about the apparent lack of success of many Aboriginal advancement programs. I think that in part is because the community has had too much exposure to the Michael Mansells of Aboriginal affairs and not nearly enough exposure to people such as Lois O'Donoghue, Ossie Cruse and the present chairperson of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Shirley McPherson. The Michael Mansells simply succeed in making ordinary, decent Australians, who would wish to help their fellow Aboriginal Australians, regard the Aboriginal movement as something which is repugnant to Australia. I believe that Michael Mansell and his friends carry a very heavy burden of responsibility for the negative attitudes towards Aboriginals which are evident in much of the community. It is tragic that the hard working, wholly admirable people of the sort that I have mentioned receive so much less coverage and publicity for what they are doing. There is some progress, there is some good being achieved and it is being achieved by people of that stamp.

Because I think there is that disillusion let me very quickly touch on some of the things that have been achieved. They have not been achieved by advocating radical solutions, they have been achieved by very hard work. Over recent years we have seen a decline in infant mortality. Over the 10 years to 1982 it has gone from 142.7 deaths per 1,000 live births to 38.3. In other words, over one decade in Australia, a decade of considerable effort, we reduced the number of infant deaths per thousand births from 142 to 38.3. That is still a very poor figure. Aboriginal infant deaths were once eight times as bad as for the rest of Australia and they are still three times as bad, but to have achieved a drop from eight times as bad to three times as bad over a decade is at least some progress. Over five years the percentage of Aboriginals with trachoma reduced from a range of between 17 to 32 per cent over four differing zones to 6 to 13 per cent. So the number of Aboriginal people with trachoma was reduced to about one-third of what it was.

Hospitalisation rates for Aboriginal people remain significantly higher than for the rest of the population, but the gap has been significantly reduced. The unemployment rate has risen, and I will return to that in a moment, but white collar employment of Aboriginals has risen from about 8 per cent of Aboriginals employed to just under 20 per cent. Since the institution of Aboriginal secondary grants, secondary school retention rates have increased although participation rates are still well below those of the rest of the community. In 1981, while 24 per cent of all Australians had post-school qualifications and the figure for Aboriginals was only 4.1 per cent, it had gone up from 2.3 per cent 10 years before. According to a survey conducted by the late Charles Rowley into rural Aboriginal housing in New South Wales in 1965, only 53 per cent of Aboriginal people were satisfactorily housed. In 1980 the figure was 93 per cent.

I mention those things because in these debates one almost never hears any reference to the fact that the work of successive governments and many hard working individuals in the communities and, most importantly, the hard work of many Aboriginal people, has achieved some very significant steps forward which I think most Australians would applaud. If those improvements were better understood and people felt that they were being built upon there would be massive support for Aboriginal advancement programs.

On the other hand, there is a very negative side to it and again I think it is important that the Government bear this in mind in making its plans for Aboriginal affairs, as the Opposition has had to do. The same survey by Dr Charles Rowley, to which I referred, showed declines in some very vital areas, and I pick out just one. In 1965-a drought year-Dr Rowley found that, among rural Aboriginals in New South Wales, the unemployment rate for men was 21 per cent. In 1980, after many years of government effort-both Labor and Liberal-and the vast expenditure of Commonwealth funds, we find an unemployment rate of 53 per cent. That is the sort of statistic that requires governments and oppositions to stop and examine the impact of some of those programs because, as I think those figures show, sometimes the impact is not all benign.

The other point I would like to raise, which is totally omitted from this statement, is something which I think is fundamentally important to future success. There is no real mention in this statement of the fact that the success or failure of most programs will depend upon Aboriginal people exercising responsibility. There is talk about the need for Aboriginal self-management and so on but the reality is that, until there is a personal sense of responsibility among Aboriginal people, many of the things which are done by politicians and administrators will fail.

The important role of Aboriginal parents is in looking after their children, seeing to their nutrition and encouraging them in their education. The importance of individual discipline in maintaining health and so on is something which I believe is inadequately emphasised by those of us who take an interest in Aboriginal affairs. I well remember Henry Schapper, a teacher at the University of Western Australia, who wrote a book on the subject. Years ago, after a weekend conference on Aboriginal affairs, he said that he was saddened that no one, white or black, had talked about the direct Aboriginal individual role in exercising responsibility and achieving success, whether it was success in having a healthy life, obtaining a job or whatever. I believe that we do a great disservice to the Aboriginal community in failing to acknowledge to Aboriginals that it is their individual acts that will be critical in the end. I think we would say to most other Australians that, in the end, their own personal efforts will be critical; I think it is wrong always to be looking to the institutional and other difficulties which Aboriginal people face, ignoring the reality that, in the end, their personal efforts will be the difference between success and failure. I am one who believes that effort in this area is worthwhile, very important, and can achieve very positive things, but I am also one who believes that we must be very cautious to ensure that Aboriginal people have an incentive to help themselves and do understand the importance of their own actions.

I turn now to the statement to look at it in a little more detail. I am glad that other Opposition speakers will be taking part in this debate, and Senator Tambling in particular who I think has a much closer knowledge than most of us of the practical on-the-ground difficulties that many policies have. Also my friend and colleague Senator Peter Baume who, like me, has been a Minister in this area, will be speaking. I only have time to touch lightly on some of the matters that have been put forward. I am glad that what I have to say will be supplemented and added to in quite different ways, no doubt, by my colleagues. The first thing that needs to be said is that there is a real confusion of ideas in the appendices which have been attached to this statement. This is important because the appendices represent the Government's suggestions as to matters which might be contained in future legislation. The particular confusion to which I wish to point is the fact that after the acknowledgment that Aboriginal people are the original owners of this land-a point which I think warrants a separate comment-we find that in the proposed preamble the Government is saying:
. . . it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision for rectification . . . of the consequences of past injustices.

One can read those words in different ways, but I would suggest very seriously to the Government that the constructive way to read those words-and, perhaps rephrase them-is to make sure that we are saying that it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision to meet the present difficulties and needs of Aboriginal Australians. The words bear that grammatical meaning but it is possible, in light of what appears in the second attachment, that what the Government means is that it will promote payments of a compensatory nature. In paragraph 3 of attachment B we find the words:
The powers and functions of the Commonwealth under the Act . . . will be enumerated separately. Among the powers so to be enumerated will be: (a) compensation for dispossession . . .

I am not sure whether there is a conflict between schedule A and schedule B or whether the Government means to say that in this legislation it intends to promote the idea that we should act on the basis of compensation for dispossession. If that is what the Government intends-and that appears to be the clear meaning of the words in attachment B-I simply record the view at this stage that that is likely to be counterproductive. My own extensive experience of talking to Australians around the country on this issue is that they will strongly support programs which are based on meeting the present needs of Aboriginal people, but it produces resentment in almost every case if one tries to put it in terms of compensation. Whatever the personal views of senators, it is my very clear impression that among the people of Australia there is a quite strong resistance to the idea that we as individuals are in some way responsible for compensation. However, there is a very great readiness to support the view that we should embrace programs which will meet the present needs of extremely disadvantaged Australians.

The other matter to which I wish to refer in the attachment is the reference to the original owners of this land. I simply say in passing that the Opposition has already recorded its concern at the apparently careless use of these words in the attachment. In response to questions in the other place, the Government has indicated that it has not even considered the possible legal implication of what it has put down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on.
—I am sorry, but if we go back to what was said in Question Time, I think we will find that no advice was taken on that aspect.
—I have given some advice.
—That almost proves my point, Senator Evans. If you have been offering advice, then I am extremely nervous for the Government's position.
—The spirit of Christmas, Fred!

—My difficulty about achieving the spirit of Christmas in this debate is, as I said earlier, that the Government has made so many mistakes in this area and has put so many Aboriginal people into a situation where they are despised and put upon in the community that I find it very hard to be lighthearted about it. However, the opening up of the issue of ownership and the suggestion that the Government should create a situation where Aboriginal people may make claims, as of rights, based on historical dispossession 200 years ago is likely-whatever arguments may be put in favour of it as a matter of justice-to produce an extremely unhappy result. I ask the Government to take that into account. My point is that I believe that that sort of upsetting and overturning of the present legal framework in Australia is something which is likely to add to the difficulties of Aboriginal people by creating even greater community difficulties and resentment than exists at present. I therefore say that the Government should not approach this as a matter of theory and as a matter of producing a warm inner glow, but should carefully consider the practical operation of what it is talking about and whether it will advance the position of Aboriginal people if it follows that course.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that is very worrying about this statement-again it is in the same context-is the comment by the Minister under the heading `A Compact or Agreement'. He stated:

There is a widely held belief that we cannot come to terms with our history unless we reach some form of compact, agreement, treaty or Makarrata-the name is not significant-between the Aboriginal and Islander and non-Aboriginal people.

I think that the Minister is grossly out of touch with reality in making that statement. He is totally out of touch with the feelings of the Australian people. It does matter. When I was Minister in 1979 and 1980 I had long and earnest conversations with the Aboriginal people around Australia about the unwisdom of using the terms `treaty' with the implication that we were claiming separate nations within Australia. I was grateful that the National Aboriginal Conference at that time accepted and adopted that viewpoint and produced its own concept of a makarrata which it explained to me and to others was based on a word which fundamentally involved the process of reconciliation. I say to the Government that talk of a treaty is foolish because it will create more of the difficulties that we have seen far too much of in this community.
I will not embarass the Senate. I am pleased to see at least one Government senator who I think has more knowledge of Aboriginal affairs than most nodding vigorously.

TALK.START.PARA: —The name is important.

—I thank Senator Collins. I appreciate support from his quarter. One of the most serious issues that people who are allegedly friendly to Aboriginals have to come to grips with is the fact that this sort of wonderful theatre can, in fact, be ultimately highly detrimental to Aboriginal people and is likely to produce an extremely adverse reaction in the Australian people. My very deep concern-I express this concern not just to the Government but to those Aboriginal people who are pushing these matters-is that we should avoid as far as possible those things that are likely to be destructive and counterproductive.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will, no doubt, be pleased to hear that I do not have very much time left, but I had wished to make some comment on the basic proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission which I think are extremely confused and confusing. I ask Government senators to look at the present Aboriginal Development Commission and to take the time and trouble to read the second reading speech which former Senator Neville Bonner, the only Aboriginal member of this Parliament that we have had so far, put down in the Senate on 17 April 1980. I ask them to do that because that sets out the extensive process of consultation which led to the formation of the ADC. The ADC represents a body which was shaped by the Aboriginal community of Australia. It is a body which is controlled by the Aboriginal Board and which is substantially free of government control. I ask why it is that this body is not being improved, updated and built upon and why we are seeking to start again. I believe that if the Government thinks that, by going through exactly the same process in 1987 and coming out with a slightly different framework, it will be doing anything more than inviting the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1992 to do the same thing, it is ignoring the lessons of history. I enter the plea that there be a sensible assessment of what the ADC is now. By all means, let us vary it, add to it, or whatever, but why start again? It is absolute insanity to think that that will produce progress for the Aboriginal community.

The last thing I want to say is that I think that the Minister must be careful not to add to the confusion which is on the ground. I hope that Senator Tambling will have a chance to talk about this. The conflicting roles of community councils and land councils, for example, is a legacy of different layers having been added to the system by different governments and different Ministers at different times. This proposal has the capacity to add considerably to the confusion of jurisdictions which will make life so very much more difficult in the Aboriginal communities. Again I see Senator Collins nodding. I defer to his more detailed knowledge of communities, as I do to Senator Tambling's more detailed knowledge of the problems in Aboriginal communities. I hope that this proposal will receive highly critical scrutiny. It is a confession of past failures. When one confesses past failures a bit of humility about where one is going from here is not lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 20 years since the 1967 referendum extended far more extensive powers to the Commonwealth Government to work for the benefit of the Aboriginal community in Australia. In that 20 years many challenges have been thrown to government that have not been properly met or picked up. It has been a confusing time of very rapid social change for the whole Australian nation, but particularly for the Aboriginal community. I invite honourable senators to think seriously about the changes in society in that 20-year period, the impact of constitutional change in that time, and, in particular, the impact that television has had across the whole of Australia. The impact of television has had a compounding effect in the Aboriginal educative process, which has produced many continuing problems. Successive governments have sought, far too patronisingly, to be involved in and to seek to solve problems for Aboriginals. They have sought to impose rules, controls and mechanisms that have not adequately or properly been met.

SPEECH.PARA: The document that has come before us on the last day of the sittings of the Senate and which came before the House of Representatives on the last day of its sittings last week-Foundations for the Future by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand-has been presented in a way which insults members of parliament. They are unable to give it the appropriate, proper and full consideration that they ought to have been able to give it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical of this Government.

—It is very typical of the style of this Government. We need to consider very carefully whether this issue is just a Bicentennial front to avoid problems in the Aboriginal radical area prior to Australia Day. We need to look very carefully at the motivations behind the way in which the document has been tabled. The Hawke Labor Government should stop fiddling with words and get on with helping Aboriginals. In regard to the preamble to the document, does one ever see a highlighting of the preamble to other legislation? But this document has been put forward in the media in the last week or so as something rather major. It is rather like a legal document, a series of statements of whereas, whereas and whereas. To me it sounds like something out of a used car sales contract. We are talking about prior ownership. We are talking about the original occupiers. To make it sound like a used car sales contract is insulting to the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginals are crying out for dignity, for better health and for education and all the Federal Government has been able to come up with, after four years, a recent change in Minister and a very deliberate change in direction between Minister Holding and Minister Hand, is a set of fancy words. One can be sure that these words will not change the shocking child mortality rates or the low life expectancy in Aboriginal communities.

I believe the Australian Labor Party is preoccupied with guilt. The proposals presented are designed only to ease its conscience and avoid demonstrations prior to the Bicentenary. I am concerned-and I will make some comments shortly-that some of the proposals that have been put forward, as Senator Chaney said, have not been given sufficient depth of thought, debate and consideration. There is a threat in many quarters-and people will read it this way-that a de facto black parliament could be included in the proposals to set up an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

I believe this Commission is doomed to fail. It is doomed to fail in the same way in which the two previous organisations-the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee and the National Aboriginal Conference-failed. I will develop that point shortly. The Labor Party, in these proposals, shows a great deal of hypocrisy. This is the Party that, in talking about new structures, particularly in parliamentary involvement, electorates and voting, refers to the one vote one value principle. What do we see in these proposals? There is a potpourri type of organisation which creates six councils and 28 regional councils throughout Australia. We need to look at the variation in population of those zones and regions. The Aboriginal population within the zones will vary in size from 14,000 in South Australia to 35,000 in the Northern Territory and 61,000 in Queensland. Yet each zone is expected to elect only one member of the Commission. So much for one vote one value! The Labor Party stands on its dig about a gerrymander in Queensland and in other places. Talk about a gerrymander that is unfair to the Aboriginal constituency!

The individual regions will vary in size from 5,000 to about 19,000. Each of those regions will elect a certain number of members. So much for one vote one value! How can Aborigines in Tasmania or Victoria expect to be treated with the same degree of equity as Aborigines in other parts of Australia when the Government is creating electorates, regions and zones with this sort of disparity? It paves the way for pressure groups and, in particular, for the part Aboriginal people who have a radical orientation, because of the problems in other parts of Australia, to exercise undue influence and control, particularly in Aboriginal issues. In that community, there is a natural inbuilt conflict between those Aboriginals who still live a tribally, culturally, ceremonially oriented environment, and those Aborigines who are of part Aboriginal descent, living in a fully urbanised community. The power, influence and effort being put into this sort of proposal builds in a mechanism that means that the organisational structure that is proposed is doomed to failure.

I am also concerned about a number of features that will override the role of State government. The Commonwealth-State relations area is always fraught with difficulty. Again, one needs to go back to basics with the Labor Party to find out what it thinks about the relationship with States and its motivations. In fact, if one refers to the famous Bob Hawke Boyer Lectures, one will find one of the very early statements of current Labor Party philosophy. I quote from Hawke's Boyer Lectures:

Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is the States-which no longer serve their original purpose and act as a positive impediment to achieving good government in our current community.

That is part of the motivation that is behind the Labor party's philosophy in looking at this particular area in such detail. There are proposals that I will come to in a minute in areas of land administration and finance that are crucial and that are being put into this proposed new set of legislation that needs to be looked at. We also need to be reminded that the functions that are being proposed for the new Commission are very widespread-right through a number of social areas, land areas, and education areas. It will mean that the new Commission will, in its first full financial year of operation, have a budget in excess of $600m to administer. That is using current Budget figures which are being used in this Parliament for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. That money is involved in the straight transfer of functions. We need to look very carefully at the accountability to the Australian taxpayers for the expenditure of that money. I accept the points that Senator Chaney made earlier that there have been problems in that area; there have been sins. But we need to be sure that we do not compound the problem by transferring it out of a parliamentary or governmental area into a commission function area and building in automatic issues.

The other area that I think needs to be addressed most seriously as a point of principle, which this statement does not do, goes right back to the essence of who is an Aboriginal. I am not raising this as a point of controversy just to get involved in redneck-type debate, but until a clear distinction is drawn between the special interests of tribal, culturally and ceremonially involved Aboriginals, basically living in communities and environments that are unique and special and those interests of other Australian citizens who are of part Aboriginal descent and who live in an urbanised community and an urbanised society with different priorities, different disabilities and special needs to be addressed-until we come back to a definition problem-we will compound the issue.

In the Northern Territory, the 35,000 Aborigines comprise some 25 per cent of the population. I would predict that 10 or 15 years into the future just about every Territory family will be related by intermarriage to an Aboriginal. I have two nephews and a niece who are part Aboriginal and they qualify for many additional and special benefits for which my children do not. The odds of my children marrying Aboriginals or part Aboriginals are quite high because of the community in which I live. I accept that but if we look to the future, all of us in the Northern Territory can just about be guaranteed that we will have, under the present definitions, Aboriginal grandchildren at least. Therefore, we need to address that. We need to ask: How do we decide whether a person is tribally and culturally linked to an environment or is a person of part Aboriginal descent with, we accept, special needs and problems in the community?

I turn now to more particular detail with regard to this. I would like to draw attention to other legislation that is already on the books. Some 533 Aboriginal associations are already incorporated and are already administered by Aboriginal people under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act. They involve basically the areas of housing, medical services, legal services, alcohol rehabilitation and sporting and community services to local communities. One needs to look at how these are based on Aboriginal custom. This proposed Commission is somehow going to have to integrate those 533 associations, plus, of course, many more that will be incorporated in the future. I am aware that the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, initiated a review of the role of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations. I have now been informed that these proposals for reform have been put on hold-put aside. Why can it not be done consistently and tied in with these new types of proposals?

The formation of the new ATSIC is basically only a regurgitation, if one looks at the detail, of the former National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) and the disbanded National Aboriginal Consultative Committee (NACC). The first of these was established by the Labor Government 14 years ago in 1973. It certainly was a very highly controversial organisation. In 1976 it became apparent that there were many problems and a special report was commissioned from Dr Hiatt to review the functions of that body. That report found that, whilst many initiatives had been undertaken, there was a real failure to establish a working relationship between the NACC and government, and in particular the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. There was a lack of consultation, and an antagonism which was built up with Aboriginal leaders right throughout Australia. We also saw in that body many very articulate urban Aboriginals dominating the European style of formal meetings at the expense of tribal representation; that brought out the conflicts to which I alluded earlier.

The NAC was the replacement organisation established by the Fraser Government. It went down a similar track; it consisted of 36 members elected on a regional basis when it was formed. But it was not long before this body also got into problems. Honourable senators will recall that Dr Coombs was brought in to inquire into the role of the Conference. His report is a sad saga of why it failed. I will list some of the reasons in a precis form. It was out of touch with Aboriginal communities. It failed to represent effectively the needs and aspirations of communities. It failed to provide a feedback of information. It was unwilling to co-operate with Aboriginal controlled service and political organisations such as land councils, which I will come to shortly. It lacked the professional expertise to carry out the work. It failed to formulate policy. It failed to negotiate funding. It was inefficient in staffing; in particular we saw the spectre of nepotism creeping in. It was extravagant and wasteful of expenditure. It did not maintain any forms of Aboriginal independence. Its power was physically restricted to a very tight executive. It failed to look at the needs in particular of Aboriginal women. It failed; it was doomed. Of course, it was dumped when the Auditor-General got into it and uncovered many fraudulent financial transactions, unauthorised expenditure and inadequate security of documents.

That brings me to the point of the structure of the proposed organisation. It is basically not very different, and this is what worries me about many of those forms of representation. The only difference is that the Conference was an advisory council; the proposed Commission is also to be given the disbursement function, and therefore the problem is that it can be seen by many in the community as bringing about a black parliament.

What are the implications for State, Territory and local governments? We must remember that Aboriginal members of the community must participate fully in those administrations because they are very much a part of them. The Northern Territory is moving rapidly towards statehood. That means that a new constitution will be devised for the Northern Territory. That constitution will have to address and pick up the special needs and concerns of Aboriginal people, particularly when they represent 25 per cent of the electorate and the population.

What about the involvement of the Commonwealth Grants Commission and the Premiers Conference? Does this new Commission, with an administration of $600m at least-about two thirds of the Northern Territory Government's vote-fully expect to be pushed and promoted, with a seat on the Premiers Conference, or will the Grants Commission have to address some very special roles? The Liberal and National parties have always emphasised the concurrent nature of Federal and State powers. If we look at these proposals, we see that there are some major problems in that these things are not necessarily concurrent. The powers and functions proposed for the new Commission include the power to compensate:
. . . for dispossession, where the measures are of a compensatory nature, including the provision of land or special programs of assistance, are impracticable or inadequate;
Moreover, it will have the function of:
recognition, and the incorporation within the Australian legal system to the extent practicable, of customary laws.

Again that bears on the essence of this relationship between State, Territory and local government areas. This matter has not been addressed in this particular proposal. I am pleased that Senator Collins is in the chamber. I note that he held a consultancy to the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, in the area of local government for Aboriginals. I am sure that he is familiar, just as I am, with the very special developments in the Northern Territory in community government, whereby Aboriginal communities are electing to go with a special-but, in a way, normal-local government system. In fact, some 26 communities have either gone into, registered to go into or expressed serious interest in participating in, community local government within the Northern Territory framework. I am fearful that some of the proposals and the heavy-handedness of this Commission will tend to override that involvement and compound problems for the Aboriginal leadership, if these people have to participate in the regional and zone politics of a new national Commission and in the local government and Territory government-as they should fully do-within the electorate of the Northern Territory.
The proposals also take up the matter of overriding the State governments' land rights policies. Amongst the functions the Commonwealth enumerated, as I just said earlier, is:
the provision, in conjunction with the States and Territories or separately-
I stress `or separately'-
of land for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people under secure long term arrangements including, wherever practicable, inalienable communal freehold title . . .

This in turn will pose a conflict in the Northern Territory with the existing structures of the land councils. There are already three land councils in the Northern Territory-the Tiwi Land Council, the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. They have an intricate system of Aboriginal leadership and participation. Suddenly the spectre of this proposal coming across the top will mean there will be involvements. The new proposals for regions would provide for five new regions. They will not pick up the present three. So I am suspicious as to whether there will be a change in the land council functions-or are they to be subsumed by this particular organisation?

I have also mentioned the need for accountability and scrutiny by Parliament. There are a quarter of a million Aboriginal people throughout Australia who are full participants in the Australian system. The Government has recognised its special role with respect to them. As I said earlier, the Commonwealth Government's programs-under the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the present Aboriginal Development Commission, and there are also the education programs under the Department of Employment, Education and Training-will mean that some $600m will be transferred automatically across to this Commission. In addition, the Commonwealth Government spends many millions in social security and in other appropriate areas. The State parliaments have a compact in their annual Budgets. The annual Budgets of this Parliament and the State governments also provide millions of dollars to Aboriginals. My estimate is that in total the Australian taxpayer contributes, quite rightly, through all of the Aboriginal programs between $1,000m and $1,200m.

I want to emphasise the aspect of consultation and the process of government that needs to be very carefully brought out in respect of this matter. There is no mention in the document of consultation with State governments or with the non-Aboriginal community. There are comments in it that I find very consistent with the recommendations that are flowing from the Constitutional Commission. That worries me because that is a new direction of government. There are some proposals to alter the Public Service arrangements. I wonder whether the head of this new organisation is to be Charlie Perkins. Everyone seems to be presuming that he will be appointed the new chief commissioner. If he is appointed, I believe his role will be rather like that of the character from Mozart's comic opera, the Abduction from the Seraglio. I believe Charlie will probably end up with the role of Osmin, the black eunuch who oversaw the harem.

I stress the point that the zones and regions proposed in this document are not consistent with good administration. They will not meet the very desperate and legitimate needs of Aboriginal people in the community. We need to look very carefully at the constitutional implications. In particular, we need to look very carefully at the inherent conflict between the tribal, ceremonial, cultural Aboriginal communities and the part-Aboriginal political interest groups that have different social and integration problems elsewhere in Australia. The Foundations for the Future is a pious document that does not adequately address the problems. As I said earlier, it regurgitates and revamps a lot of past work. It does not go anywhere near meeting the needs of Aboriginal people in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foundations for the Future statement made on 10 December by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) deserves some congratulation. It is a long overdue acknow-ledgment of Aboriginal people's prior occupation of this country. I do not want to get bogged down in party politicking on this issue, but there are some very important philosophical underpinnings to this statement which need to be given priority. In dealing with Aboriginal issues there are many complicating factors. Some of them have been outlined by Senator Tambling and Senator Chaney this morning. I do not think it is appropriate at this stage to blame particular political parties for past misdeeds. It should be a shared community responsibility, on the part of all Australians, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal.

SPEECH.PARA: For a long time, I have been saying that we would neither have nor deserve peace and justice in this country unless and until we publicly, as a nation, made the acknowledgment of prior occupation of Australia by Aboriginal people. While I congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on having finally pronounced the words, it is also important to look at the actions or inactions which lie behind those words and the timing of this gesture. On the subject of timing, it is incredible that it has taken 200 years for the invading Europeans to have the grace to say to Aboriginal people, `You were here first'. The reluctance has obviously been tied to a realisation of the implications of such a public statement: raising questions of both rights and sovereignty which must be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong, Senator. It was done ten years ago.

—No. Ten years ago, there was an acknowledgment of Aboriginal people's existence, but there has never been a public acknowledgment of Aboriginal people's prior claim to this land. This is where this statement is significantly different in a legal sense. For 200 years, non-Aboriginal Australians have managed to ignore the basic premise on which our Australian society is founded: the invasion by the British to establish a convict settlement. That part, of course, has been acknowledged, but the consequence of that invasion, the dispossession of the indigenous people, has never been acknowledged up to now. Everywhere else the British went they made a treaty with the indigenous people, but not here. This official recognition is 200 years overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as far as it goes, it is very welcome, I hope, to Aboriginal Australians and to many non-Aboriginals who have long been uncomfortable with the dispossession of Australia's original inhabitants. There have always been many non-Aboriginal Australians who have felt deeply moved by the plight of Aboriginal people. Many have felt outraged by the gross injustices which have sometimes systematically and sometimes thoughtlessly been dealt out to Aboriginal people. But, against all odds, Aboriginal people have survived. Against all plans and schemes to dispossess, even to exterminate them, they have survived-a remarkable achievement considering the massacres, the diseases introduced by Europeans, the poisoning of their waterholes and the takeover of their living spaces and food supplies.

The most important loss for Aboriginal people has been access to their land. The cultural and spiritual ties to the land are the lifeblood of the Aboriginal people. Removed from the earth, their mother, to which they belong, rather than the other way round as we non-Aboriginal people would generally have it, they have been robbed of the very essence of their collective being. This alienation from traditional roots could almost have decimated Aboriginal culture. But, thankfully, that did not quite happen. So having survived against all odds is probably the one thing that Aboriginal people can celebrate in this otherwise embarrassing Bicentenary.

Aboriginal people are still here in the land of their dreaming and they are strong in their efforts to maintain their culture, their dignity and their ageless connection with this land. We, the non-Aboriginal inhabitants, ought to listen to the many voices of Aboriginal people and learn from the richness of their traditional culture, which was based on sharing, renewal and harmony with the environment. After 200 years, maybe we are finally ready to listen not only to Aboriginal calls for land rights, which I think we should heed, but also to the wisdom of traditional Aboriginal culture, which, unlike ours, was not based on exploitation and rampant consumerism.

While I generally want to commend Gerry Hand for putting together this public acknowledgment, for having the guts to do it in the certain knowledge that there will be some conservative racist backlash, I must also point out that the timing of this statement is significant for its opportunism. How embarrassing for Australia trying to `celebrate'-and I use that word in inverted commas because I think we should be commemorating rather than celebrating-200 years of European settlement and not to have made peace with the original inhabitants of this land. How embarrassing it is when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) chastises the Soviet Union's human rights record but is in turn rebuked for the appalling conditions in which most of our indigenous people live. It is absolutely fair that he was publicly shown up for being hypocritical. Of course, it is not only the Prime Minister who should be taken to task in this regard, but all Australians of all political persuasions. It should be a shared and collective responsibility.

This exposure of Australia's hypocrisy is happening increasingly in international fora and it will continue throughout the Bicentenary and World Expo 88 in Brisbane, statement or no statement. When the eyes of the world are on Australia it will be embarrassing in the extreme for the truth to emerge about the history of the appalling treatment of Aboriginal people and their continuing suffering. It is a national disgrace that we have so many people living in Third World conditions in this very affluent country.

Why has it taken the death of about 80 Aboriginal people in custody finally to focus the attention of the nation on the plight of Aboriginal people in our community? For years we have known that Aboriginal people, who constitute around 2 per cent of our population, constitute abut 30 per cent of our prison populations. Figures were not enough to stir us into action, to get us to ask the necessary questions to explain why these figures are so high. We have not wanted to admit that there have been massive problems for Aboriginal people dispossessed of their land, their spirituality, trying to cope with an alien society imposed upon them by a foreign invading force. We just expected them to adapt to the ways of the invading culture.

We have heard here this morning in the chamber that, whatever Aboriginal people do, they seem to be in a no-win situation as non-Aboriginal people make judgments about their behaviour. If they are traditional, that seems to be okay to a degree, but, if they are non-traditional urban Aboriginal people who try to work within the framework of European culture and have some input into the decision-making processes about their own futures, they are criticised for being manipulative and too radical. It seems that they cannot win either way. They must take responsibility and yet, as soon as they try to take some responsibility, they are criticised as being too radical.

Tragically, our imposing of our European standards on the Aboriginal people has not worked. Neither will this new package outlined by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) work unless there is better understanding in our community of the fundamental truths of Aboriginal culture. We must stop highlighting the negative stereotypes which, unfortunately, are only too easy to find and teach our children-and I am here referring to non-Aboriginal children-a genuine appreciation of Aboriginal culture. We must respect and cherish Aboriginal people's collective being in this country for almost 40,000 years. We need also to provide essential services to back up the rhetoric of this historic acknowledgment.

Aboriginal people need to see some immediate effects of this statement, such as the provision of adequate water supplies to all communities. The basic and fundamental needs have not been met by any number of bureaucracies trying to provide services but, in fact, not really listening to the voices of Aboriginal people and providing for their basic needs. If there is no immediate effect, we will find Aboriginal people dismayed at words and more words but lack of action, feeling fobbed off by yet another government inquiry and feeling that decision making on Aboriginal issues still is not in Aboriginal hands. This dismay reflects a deeply-felt desire for self-determination. For example, why will the Chairperson and four of the seven counsellors of the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission be appointed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs? Why will not all the counsellors be elected by the people they will represent? It does not sound like a recipe for Aboriginal self-determination.

The establishment of this new layer of bureaucracy is confusing. I agree with Senator Chaney that there is no need to re-invent the wheel. A bureaucratic smokescreen is not going to satisfy Aboriginal Australians. However, to return to the most significant and positive aspect of the Minister's statement, the long overdue recognition of Aboriginal people's prior claim to this land, it is my hope that such a national acknowledgment will find widespread acceptance in the community. Affirmation by the community at large is essential if we are to move forward constructively, firstly to stop the abuses of human rights still being heaped on Aboriginal people and, secondly, to encourage self-determination for Aboriginal people so that their rightful and proud place as the indigenous people of Australia can be fully reclaimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no more difficult area of government activity than the area of Aboriginal affairs, whether it relates to policy, consultation processes or administration. Senator Chaney spoke today with all the experience of a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and laid out for us some of the difficulties. To hold the post of a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs leaves a deep and lasting impression on any person who is so fortunate. Holders of that office are changed permanently. If one cares for Aboriginal Australia, about some of the things to which Senator Vallentine referred, about some of the past treachery and murder, some of the deprivation and brutality, some of the dispossession and the present disadvantage which is enormous and continuing and if one cares about the racism which continues in this country, one sees that appointment within the government as an opportunity to do something, an opportunity to try to bring about change.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone, such as Mr Gerry Hand, who is given the opportunity to take over as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will try to grasp that opportunity to bring about some change and to achieve some different outcomes. To change the structures and the bodies within the portfolio, and perhaps to change the people, is not to change outcomes. What the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has proposed is that he is going to change the structures and create, perhaps, some new winners and losers. He is going to alter the processes. But none of those things matter, none can be justified or are worth anything unless, at the same time, the Minister can tell us that he will change outcomes for Aboriginal people. It is not just a question of money, rhetoric or structures.

I would like to examine what has been proposed in this document, Foundations for the Future. I would like to look at the context and what this document does to alter the context in which we operate, to look at the structures and the activities which are proposed, and to think a little bit about outcomes. Some parts of the document deserve praise. Whatever the drawbacks-and Senator Chaney drew attention to some of those-it is worth looking at the context which the Minister is trying to establish. Senator Vallentine does not know her history. It is a pity because she is committed and passionate. She says there has never been any statement of prior ownership. I am delighted that Mr Hand has decided to build upon the motion moved in this place in the 1970s by Liberal senator, Neville Bonner, a motion which was moved here on 19 September 1974. At that time, Senator Bonner moved a motion in the following terms:

That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.

That motion, proposed by Senator Bonner on 19 September 1974, was adopted unanimously by the Senate in this chamber on 20 February 1975. The Australian Senate at that time, by adopting that motion, admitted prior ownership, called for the Government to introduce legislation and called for compensation for dispossession. It is simply not correct to say that what Mr Hand has done is entirely new. But it is nonetheless welcome. The fact that Mr Hand wants to build upon the motion which Senator Bonner, as the only Aboriginal ever to serve as a parliamentarian in this Parliament, proposed some 13 years ago-a motion which this Senate was happy to endorse-seems to us to be a very important historical matter. I am just sorry that Mr Hand's statement made no reference to Senator Bonner, to his proposal, or to the endorsement by the Senate some 13 years ago of that motion. Mr Hand's statement acknowledges some of the measures of present disadvantage and unmet need. For that we are grateful. That is important. It accepts the need for self-determination on the part of Aboriginal people. It says:
Aboriginal people need to decide for themselves what should be done-not just whatever governments think or say is best for them.

That is fine, but it has to be qualified. Having been the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I have to say that some of the things which Aboriginal people decide or feel should be done are often absolutely impractical and impossible to achieve. I remind the Senate that one of the Aboriginal activists, at the time the makarrata was being discussed, laid down as one of the prior conditions that there should be made available to Aboriginal people, a set percentage of the gross domestic product, free of tax, for 190 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —One per cent.

—Was it? That was an ambit claim by an Aboriginal activist but we are not going to say that self-determination goes to that extent. There has to be some negotiation and brokerage. I accept and endorse self-determination but it, like anything else, has to be looked at within the realms of what is possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us leave the question of context because what this document, Foundations for the Future, is really about is altering the structures which serve the Aboriginal community and through which programs are given to them. The changes which have been proposed are enormous. It is proposed that an Aboriginal affairs commission be established-that was the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Indeed, that has been done through the establishment of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It will incorporate four existing bodies: the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. So if this proposal is pushed through, the new body will be established and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is to go-to disappear. Its functions will cease. It will cease to operate as one of the departments of state. Why is that being done? This is the Department which, after a torrid time in the mid-1970s, went through the most searching departmental examination and analysis that I have ever known, came through that fire tempered and efficient and was the best department of state with which I was ever associated as a Minister. There is no doubt about that. It was a tough, lean, effective department.

Why is the Department to go? It has an established record of achievement, it has established processes, established structures and established networks, it has existing expertise and it has long experience. Is what is in the mind of the Minister, Mr Hand, that he wants to Aboriginalise all activities to do with Aboriginal affairs? That may be a romantic idea, but he has got to understand that there is not an Aboriginal administrative cadre big enough to undertake that purpose and, if there is, it can only be done by bleeding all other Aboriginal organisations and other parts of the Aboriginal community of the expertise which they would otherwise have available to them. The whole idea that only Aboriginal people can administer the efforts of the Australian Government in relation to Aboriginal affairs is crazy. Do we argue that only veterans should be able to administer programs to do with veterans' affairs? Of course we do not. We understand that there are administrative purposes, administrative processes and administrative priorities which have to be done by trained and expert administrators.

I ask why the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is to be abolished. If we are told that the same officers would go across to the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, then we have to ask what is going to be achieved. We have not been told that, but if we were we would have to ask what the change will achieve. It will bring my friend and colleague Mr Charles Perkins into a position of greater power and influence and I have no objection to that, but that is not sufficient purpose in itself. The Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS) is to be disestablished.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will lose my job.

—Senator Crichton- Browne will know, as those who served before him on the AIAS will know, that this is a body which is both distinguished and a specialised agency. It is an interface between the three groups-Aboriginal Australians, government and the academic community. It undertakes specialised jobs-for example, the recording of Aboriginal culture, the taking of oral history and the preservation of languages. It is a cultural body, again with a record of achievement, with networks, established procedures and quite expert staff. Are the staff to go across? Are they to be dismissed? It already has a very large Aboriginal component, as Senator Crichton-Browne will know from the meetings and, as time has gone on, the members of it have learnt to assert their wishes and have them put into action. I saw Mr Ken Colbung, whom I have known for many years, the other week.
—He is a friend of mine.

—He is a friend of Senator Crichton-Browne's and he is the Chairman of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies. He was up here, very concerned about what these changes would mean, not just for his organisation but for the functions that it undertakes on behalf of Aboriginal people and the community. If it is to go, why is it to go? I invite honourable senators to look at the statement that has been made by the Minister, Mr Hand. Among some of the desirable objectives that he has set, he has offered no justification or explanation for why these organisations are to be brought together under this single umbrella.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Aboriginal Development Commission. Senator Chaney was unduly modest. That was something that he steered through parliamentary processes and the Cabinet, and former Senator Neville Bonner delivered the second reading speech for the Bill that established it. It is a body that has come through a fairly turbulent few years to a position where it is now a successful, strong and much more effective body. Is it to go? What does the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) think about all this? I have today's Sydney Morning Herald in which Mrs Shirley McPherson, the Chairman of the ADC, had some things to say. She described the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as:
nothing more than an upstart crow dressed in parrot's plumes.
She went on to explain what she meant by saying that the decision:
To replace the four main Federal Aboriginal affairs bodies, would be nothing more than the old department under a new name.

Is she right or is she wrong? If she is right, will the Minister please explain what it is that he is setting out to do? If he intends to disestablish the ADC and pass all its assets, all the capacity that it has, to the new Commission, why is that being done? It is all very well the Minister telling us that he wants to create winners, but nothing in this world is cost free. There are costs and benefits and a prudent Minister would set out the costs as well as the benefits as he goes along.

Finally, and most importantly, why is the Aboriginal Hostels Ltd going to be disestablished? This would be the most effective Aboriginal organisation that has existed in this country in the last 15 or 20 years. Its record is one of achievement. It produces outcomes. It houses Aboriginal people. If one wants to see what Aboriginal Hostels Ltd does, it will tell you what it does in terms of the number of houses built, the number of beds provided, the number of people in shelter. It is not a question of rhetoric; it is a question of performance; so why is it to be disestablished and brought under this new umbrella. What will happen in the outcome? Who will be taken across?
When one looks at the question of structures, the Minister's statement raises as many, or more, questions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Many more.

—It raises many more questions than it attempts to answer. A structural analysis would lead us to say that the Minister proposes to disestablish a number of bodies which I think are good bodies, which have been effective bodies and which are ongoing bodies with expertise and good staff, which have been developing and training as they go. The Minister has done so without establishing sound reasons, without identifying the advantages to be gained and without identifying for us the cost to be paid, without setting out the arrangements to be made for the transfers and with no word of praise in his statement for the work, the history, the efforts, the achievements, the record or the commitment of any one of those four organisations. There is not a word of praise for the care, or for the achievements to which they can look back, nor a word of praise for distinguished Australians such as Lois O'Donoghue of Aboriginal Hostels, for example. They are distinguished Australians who have contributed so much. That is a pity, because the Minister is trying to help and to improve the situation and to leave his mark.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the processes of what the Minister wants to do. We see that he wants to set up this new Commission and, as Senator Tambling has said, a Federal structure in which Aboriginal people will have some input into the representation on the new Commission. Again, he has given only the briefest of outlines. The map enclosed in the statement worries me. I look at my own State of New South Wales and I see that, from just west of the Blue Mountains right up to the border of Queensland and South Australia is to be one region. I cannot remember how many National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) electorates that used to cover, but this will give anyone who is called on to represent that area an impossible task. Honourable senators who know Aboriginal Australia will know just how difficult it is for a single representative to represent such a large area. Senator Collins is in the chamber. With the old NAC electorates around Alice Springs, as they used to exist-Senator Tambling will confirm this-where several tribal areas were concerned in one electorate and the NAC member came from one or other of those communities, he would be accepted by one, but find it almost impossible to be an effective representative to others. There are very real worries about the activities and processes which the Minister has identified.

Secondly, as other senators have said, the large number of people appointed to the Commission must give rise to some concern. Obviously, it is an attempt to maintain a maximum of ministerial control. There is no outline in the statement of the proposed accountability of the new Commission-accountability either to Aboriginal people or to the Parliament. Whether we like it or not, the new Commission will be giving effect to Government programs and Government policies. It will be using money provided from the general body of taxpayers. Questions of accountability are proper. They are proper for two reasons: firstly, because they apply to all of us and, secondly, and especially so, because in Aboriginal affairs in this country things just do not have to be clean; they have to be more than squeaky clean if we are to maintain the community consensus on which the funding of these programs exists. There is simply no mention of the accountability requirements.

I will refer now to one of the problems in the Aboriginal affairs area; and I have to say this as someone who has been involved in the area. I am not talking about the fairytale picture that some people present of how we must do this and do that, et cetera. The reality of what happens is that Aboriginal people and Aboriginal organisations are as good, as bad, as dishonest, as honest, as the rest of the Australian community. They are no better and no worse. Anyone dealing in the area of Aboriginal affairs will discover that they are dealing with a number of saints and a number of criminals. Questions of accountability and responsibility are as applicable and important here as they are anywhere else. They are not covered in the statement, which is a pity. A rousseauean concept of Aboriginal Australia as a series of noble savages is not only wrong but also dangerous and demeaning. I think the statement of the Minister illustrates some tendency to take a rousseauean view. I think that is likely to be almost as flawed a view as that of the people of an opposite persuasion who tend to denigrate Aboriginal people because of their race and who tend to take a very destructively racist view of Aboriginal Australia.

From my experience as Minister, the facts are that many Aboriginal individuals and organisations play the game impeccably. They use money responsibly. But many Aboriginal people and many Aboriginal organisations cheat outrageously. They cheat their fellows. The allocation of resources within Aboriginal communities is sometimes done by the most brutal means. They are often quite arbitrary. If a housing association is given money to build three houses when 20 houses are needed, who will get the three houses? Sometimes the decision making in that regard is entirely arbitrary; sometimes it owes more to kinship obligations than it does to questions of equity, as we would understand them. That is okay. However, we have to understand that these are the things that happen. I must say that there are management successes and management failures in Aboriginal affairs which have to be part of any analysis of changes which are proposed to be made.

Finally, I refer to the question of outcomes. These are all that matter. Senator Chaney drew our attention to some figures, I think, on infant mortality. These are outcome measures. If we want to know whether we are doing well, it is not on the basis of what our intentions are, it is not what our rhetoric is; it is what we produce at the end of the day. There are few outcomes in this statement. I hope that there is a commitment not just to processes and structures to do with education, health, housing and employment but also to producing better outcomes. Certainly, that was what drove me. I said, `Give me the figures!'. For example, we could say that Aboriginal health figures were disgraceful. These were three times the sickness rates of non-Aboriginal communities. However, if they were looked at as a function of time we could see that they were improving rapidly. Outcome measures like that are what we have to seek.

I invite honourable senators to look at the ministerial statement. There is very little in it about the outcomes which are being pursued-the outcomes which will be required by the Minister and which will be necessary to judge the success or otherwise of what he is doing. I think that it is highly desirable that Mr Hand, in taking the next step, should lay down those outcome measures by which he will judge his initiative, by which he will judge the success of what he is proposing in this statement and by which he will evaluate what he is hoping to undertake now. We will need to evaluate in the next few years the better outcomes which might be produced as a result of the Minister's initiatives. Nothing else will do in the end. It is only whether there are fewer Aborigines in gaol, more people in jobs, more people satisfied with the kind of lives they are living, more people whose children do not have trachoma, and so on. This is the greatest defect of the ministerial statement. It says nothing about outcomes. It indicates no performance outcomes which the Minister will require.

If this paper by the Minister entitled Foundations for the Future brought down last week is but a precursor of other documents and other initiatives, then those of us who care about Aboriginal Australia will wait. We will wait to see what the Minister produces. I do not intend to prejudge. I do not intend to take a negative view. We will wait for more detail and we will wait for answers that are lacking at present. We will keep an open mind and we will continue to do what we can do to assist this Government or any government to help those Australians who are Aboriginal. That means keeping an open mind on these proposals and on the details as they emerge. However, all that we have at the present is a very broad statement of intent and an intimation of very severe structural change within the area of Aboriginal affairs with, as yet, no guarantee that any particular outcomes will flow. To be active and to change things is simply not enough. To be effective is necessary too. It is effectiveness that we will be seeking from the Government when it puts changes into place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: -We are discussing a statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) entitled Foundations for the Future. The Government's proposals announced last week by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs are a milestone in the advancement of Aboriginal affairs. For the first time Aboriginals will be in charge of all matters in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio through an all Aboriginal commission. For the first time Aboriginal people throughout Australia will themselves have a say in selecting the people who will make the decisions on their behalf. For the first time Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in each region of Australia, however remote from Canberra, will have a voice in determining the priorities of their region. For the first time the Parliament will be acknowledging in legislation the plain and undeniable truth that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders were the prior occupiers and original owners of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is significant, as Senator Peter Baume has pointed out, that these changes have been proposed 12 years after the first decision on this matter was made in this chamber. I would just like to emphasise that point because the draft preamble seeks to do no more than acknowledge the facts: Australia was inhabited before 1788; the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders did own the land according to their laws; they were dispossessed of the land-a fact that Parliament has previously acknowledged in section 3 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980; and they now have no recognised rights over that land other than those granted by the Crown. Those are plain unvarnished statements of truth. We are not rewriting history but surely we are mature enough as a nation to admit that European settlement in this country was based on a legal doctrine that can now be described only as an insult to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and to their rich, ancient and complex cultures. Recognition of prior ownership should do much to repair the understandable sense of grievance of Australia's indigenous peoples at the events of history. All non-Aboriginal Australians can surely welcome this as a just and necessary part of the processes of reconciliation. No Australian's back yard is threatened by this proposal. Some concern has also been expressed that the Government's proposals may create a system of claims for compensation. The proposed preamble acknowledges the fact that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples were dispossessed without compensation. Surely that, too, is undeniable. Surely this fact was recognised 20 years ago when the Australian people voted overwhelmingly for the Commonwealth to have the power to do something for the Aboriginal people. To take action to overcome our national shame in this matter-it is a national shame-is most important. In attachment B to the Minister's statement, paragraph 3 states:
(a) compensation for dispossession, where other measures of a compensatory nature, including the provision of land or special programs of assistance, are impracticable or inadequate . . .

That is the simple fact of the matter, and that expresses the concern which I believe Australian people 20 years ago charged us with. I acknowledge in this debate the contribution of former Ministers, Senator Chaney and Senator Peter Baume, and I respect the views they have indicated. Senator Baume referred to outcomes. I am very confident that my colleague Mr Hand is just as sincere as they were, and I am also confident that this is the beginning of a new era. I will not continue; I will defer to my colleague Senator Collins who, I acknowledge, is an expert on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are discussing-I use the word advisedly-rather than debating the document titled Foundations for the Future, which is described as a policy statement. It is not legislation, but it sets out a number of matters in relation to the directions in which the Government is presumably intending to move. I particularly welcomed the remarks of Senator Vallentine and Senator Peter Baume this morning, with respect to the identification of a necessity for an attitudinal change as being far more important than a structural change. I was a little concerned, however, to note that Senator Baume pointed out that the Senate had moved a motion as long ago as 13 years, which called on the Government to legislate in this area. I simply draw attention to the fact that this legislation is still not on the books and that the policy document before us does not set out an intention to legislate, but rather to introduce a piece of legislation establishing a commission, the preamble to which would say certain things.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope I will not be accused later on by Senator Peter Baume of having a rousseauean idea of a noble savage, but I do want to deal at some length with the contrast between Aboriginal attitudes to environment and the prevailing white cultural attitude to environment, because I think there are important differences that need to be picked up.
