I was a little concerned to hear Senator Chaney imply-I thought-that if only Aborigines were more like us, that is Europeans, somehow or other the problem would disappear. If I interpreted his remarks correctly, it seems to me that that may well be identified as the basis of much our problem, not the Aboriginal problem.

The Australian Democrats welcome this policy statement, and again I draw attention to the fact that it is a policy statement, by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). The statement is important for two reasons. Firstly, it is a statement of the Government's and the Minister's thinking at the present time, and it clarifies where we stand on this most important subject at the end of 1987, that is, on the eve of the so-called Bicentenary. Secondly, by setting out where we are, it defines how far we still have to go before we achieve a truly wholesome integrated and caring Australian society. On the one hand, the statement marks a considerable advance and, on the other, the very process of identifying the needs and the proposals for improvement underscores just how far we are as a society from the goal of reconciliation.

It is perhaps significant that the statement is titled Foundations for the Future. Is it a foundation on which we can build the house which all Australians will want to call home after the next 200 years? It is impossible to consider this statement of Government intent with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples without also considering the meaning and purpose of the Bicentenary and what is meant by the word `Future' in the title. It is coincidental, but nonetheless moving, to note that 40,000 is 200 squared. We are about to celebrate 200 years of European occupation while Aboriginal people have been in Australia 200 times 200 years. Forty thousand years is an impossibly long time to imagine. By analogy, if a journey from Fremantle to Sydney represents the period of Aboriginal occupation of Australia, the period of European occupation is represented by a journey from Fremantle to Perth. Or, if the period of Aboriginal occupation is represented by one whole year, Europeans have been in this land for less than a quarter of an hour. We know that Aborigines inhabited this land for a very, very long time before Europeans came and expropriated that land. It is therefore a lie to pretend for a moment longer the legal fiction of terra nullius. Of course, Australia was not the only country in which land was forcibly acquired from its indigenous people and in which a continuous cultural clash has persisted for hundreds of years since that acquisition. The same occurred in North and South America and also in Africa.

Europeans possessed two qualities in greater measure than indigenous people. They were more aggressive and they possessed superior arms. In 1987, as the super-powers point 50,000 nuclear warheads at each other, some of us at least have begun to wonder whether these qualities define those of European origin as superior or merely stupid. For in biological terms it is survival which is the ultimate value. Indigenous people learnt and incorporated into their culture a range of attitudes, behaviour patterns and social customs which allowed them to live within the ability of their environment to sustain itself for very long periods of time. In contrast, homo sapiens europeanensis has developed a relationship of exploitation and pillage to the environment, which is clearly not sustainable for any reasonable length of time. It is Europeans who must relearn that which lies at the core of indigenous cultures, indeed which was at the heart of our culture until just a few thousand years ago. Thus it is the Europeans who must change and re-adopt that reverence for the environment which was, and still is in part, the mainspring of Aboriginal culture.

There are broadly two things wrong with this statement Foundations for the Future. Firstly, it fails to address adequately the matter of prior occupancy and so-called Aboriginal land claims; and secondly, it still treats Aboriginal culture as having no relevance to mainstream Australia, with no contribution to make to a new, viable and embracing Australian culture. It creates mechanisms to incorporate Aboriginal people into the existing mainstream Aboriginal culture of Australia which necessarily involves a rejection of that part of their culture which both they and we need for our very survival.

Earlier this year the Government passed legislation which specifically rejected Victoria's acknowledgment of prior Aboriginal occupancy. In the document now before us it is proposed to establish a commission, by legislation the preamble to which officially recognises for the first time that `Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land'.

I accept what Senator Baume has said with respect to that claim. As part of a preamble it is doubtful what force, if any, such words would have in law. The Australian Democrats have always held the view that prior occupation by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples must be established in law. That is the true and just position and we must not shirk the responsibility which such legal recognition would place upon us by cleverness with the use and the placing of words. The Opposition claimed quite recently that even including such words in a preamble `could be used to undermine the constitutional framework of Australia'. I remind members of the Opposition that as recently as 1981, when they were in government, they said:
The Government is prepared to acknowledge prior occupation of Australia by Aboriginals.

I hope that what they meant by that was that they were prepared to acknowledge that by way of legislation. So the Democrats make a plea that both the present Government and the Opposition support writing into legislation recognition of the prior occupation of Australia by Aboriginal people. But it is not legislation which is now before us so I also make the plea that both the Government and the Opposition make a commitment to support in principle this legal recognition. Of course, the legality of land rights will flow from such recognition, and so it should. The European attitude to land-as something to be exploited, its resources turned to profit and the land left denuded and derelict-must be changed and where better to learn this new attitude than from that part of the Australian population which managed this land for 40,000 years? I would like to quote Patrick Dodson on the Aboriginal attitude to land, and contrast that with the exploitative attitude of European settlers. He said:

For the Aboriginal people, land is a dynamic notion, something creative. Land is not bound by geographical limitations placed on it by a surveyor, who marks out an area and says, `This is your plot'. Land is the generation point of existence, the maintenance of existence, the spirit from which Aboriginal existence comes.
Land is a living place made up of sky, clouds, rivers, trees, the wind, the sand and the spirit has created all these things, the spirit that planted my own spirit here, my own country.
It is something-and yet it is not a thing-it is a living entity. It belongs to me, I belong to the land. I rest in it. I come from there.

Land is a notion that is most difficult to categorise in English law, but it is something that is very clear in Aboriginal law. The limitations of my land are clear to me and to those people who belong in my group. Land provides for my physical needs and provides for my spiritual needs. It is a regeneration of stories.
New stories are sung from contemplation of the land, stories are handed down from spirit men of the past who have deposited the riches at various places.
The sacred places are not just simply geographically beautiful. They are holy places, even more holy than shrines, but not commercialised. They are sacred.

The greatest respect is shown to them and they are used for the regeneration of history-the regeneration of Aboriginal people, the continuation of their life. That is where they begin and that is where they return.

And that is precisely where we, the Europeans who have occupied this land, must also return. What we call Australian culture was brought into Australia from the United Kingdom and Ireland. Our culture was brought from somewhere else. It totally excluded the Aborigines and made them marginal in their own land so that they neither received from the culture nor contributed to it; we simply pushed them aside. The categorisation of land according to whether or not it is used commercially is a reflection of an emphasis upon meeting the needs of consumers. It is one example of the error of materialism whereby directly or indirectly the spiritual and personal-human dignity, community and moral values-is subordinated to material reality. The cultural meaning of land is limited to its physical or material usefulness and that marks the contrast between the European and the Aboriginal attitude to land.

There are a number of ways in which we might address this problem, and I would just like to mention a couple. Several years ago the issue of Aboriginal land claims in Western Australia was very prominent. During the time when this issue was being strongly and publicly debated in Western Australia the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) launched a massive campaign to defeat those Aboriginal land claims. I have made the point before in this chamber, and I make it again, that we have created structures which place far greater emphasis on commercial considerations that on considerations of elements of sacredness towards land, to which I referred a moment ago, to the extent that AMIC was able to claim all its advertising expenses incurred in defeating those Aboriginal land claims as tax deductions, whereas those who had the public interest at heart, those who had the Aboriginal interest at heart, to the extent that they wished to advertise their points of view, could do so only out of income on which income tax had already been paid. Again I stress that the use of tax deductibility in this way is a pernicious mechanism by which the emphasis on commercial exploitation is able to express dominance over a caring attitude.

Secondly I refer to the Governor-General's Speech-I did so in my maiden speech-which indicates that the Government is placing emphasis on greater competitiveness in Australian society. The Governor-General, in his Speech, said that we need to become more competitive. That is precisely the direction which takes us further away from the indigenous culture of the Aborigine-a culture which placed great emphasis on co-operation and caring, an emphasis which we need to rediscover if we are to survive in this land for a further 200 years. Thirdly, one could point to a migration program in which we seek to bring in people who have already learnt the art of exploitation in their own countries-I refer to those who have more than half a million dollars-yet we place no requirements on our migrant intakes in relation to their care and knowledge of the land. Indeed, several weeks ago I spoke to Aborigines who said to me that, if they were outside this country seeking admission, they would probably not be admitted to Australia as migrants.

Fourthly, one can point to the way in which some aspects of Aboriginal culture have been superficially incorporated into white culture; for example the buying and selling of Aboriginal art and the use of Aboriginal dance as a means of entertainment for which money is paid. It seems to me that those things represent a prostitution of the function of those forms of expression and I believe that we need to move further towards the attitude of Aboriginal culture to such expressions, rather than embrace the exploitative attitude that is present in white society.

I conclude by saying that we need to change our attitudes. We need to adopt the attitudes which are present within the Aboriginal culture. One of the advantages which we might gain from the so-called Bicentenary is to use it as a time for stocktaking, a time in which rather than telling the Aborigines that we are prepared to incorporate them into the mainstream of white society, and how we will do that, we tell them that we recognise their prior ownership of the land and the elements within their indigenous culture which are not only necessary to Aboriginal survival but are also vital to the survival of every civilisation on the face of this planet. If we go down that road, we will eventually come to the point where we have a new and different culture-one which cares for the environment, takes a longer term view and attempts to live in conformity with the ability of the environment to maintain itself and survive. Eventually, when we reach that goal we will no longer need a Department of Aboriginal Affairs, an Aboriginal Commission or anything else because we will, indeed, be one people. That is what we should be working towards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking about the policy statement Foundations for the Future, concerning the reorganisation of our administrative organs for Aboriginal affairs. It represents a massive reorganisation, but I do not see any encouraging signs that this reorganisation will be any more beneficial than those we have had in the past. However, it comes at a time when there have been some very encouraging signs about an approaching comity between the traditional Aboriginal people and our own Australian society. One of those encouraging signs was mentioned in the debate this morning-that is, the ability of the tribal Aboriginals to establish themselves in a working relationship at local government level. The other sign, which is happening at this very minute, is the traditional Aborigines' ability to adapt themselves to the adversary type of legal system that we have in Australia. I will expound on these later, but I think it is encouraging that the tribal people are advancing in both these areas and it is only in the last few years that they have been able to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Ownership of land has been mentioned today, as has the definition of an Aboriginal. I am pleased that the representatives of areas which are particularly associated with Aborigines have brought up those matters because I think they are fundamental. Our tribal Aborigines are precious to us and they do not particularly recognise people who are non-traditional Aborigines. In fact, they say that they are the white man's problem, that they represent the results of colonisation. I suppose that we could say they represent the results of many private treaties that have been reached over the years.

The issue of the treaty has been brought up lately. I know that the tribal Aboriginals do not want a treaty because they do not regard themselves as being members of a different nation from the rest of Australia. In fact, they regard themselves as Australians. When I have spoken to them, over many years, I have found that by and large the traditional Aborigines do not even want the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. They say it is interfering with their family and tribal discipline. They say that they are Australians and that there is already an education department, a health department and all the other departments. They just want to fit in with those and they feel that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs interferes with their discipline.

At the time of the construction of the land councils-the three major ones in the Northern Territory were the Central, Northern and Tiwi land councils-I talked to the tribal elders when the Government was trying to arrange an election for the people to administer the councils. The tribal elders said, `Well, we cannot stand for election; we are already in charge of our areas and if you want us to stand for election to administer some other fellow's land then we cannot do it'. We wound up appointing a whole lot of unrepresentative councils that had no real authority over the tribal areas. In fact, I found that tribal areas were well demarcated. The Aborigines knew them very well and had a very sound administration of them. If anybody wanted to come on to their land he had to stand on the border. They could tell from the way he was standing and carrying his equipment whether he wanted to hunt on the land, just pass through or possibly court a girl. The penalties for trespass on the land were very severe.

As I have said, ownership has been mentioned this morning. The Aborigines' idea of ownership is entirely different from the European idea. It is a kind of spiritual ownership. The Aborigines count themselves as part of the land, wind, trees and streams. When we come along and want to buy land or have any control over its administration, they say, `Well, how do we sell you the wind and the rain? How do we sell you the smell of the flowers in springtime?'. These are all part of the Aborigines' idea of land ownership. Their dreaming over the land is important to them and is part of their ownership. In fact, the dreaming can go over hill and dale and over the next area of land administration. It can go over pastoral leases, drilling rigs and towns, and still the Aborigine feels that that establishes part of his ownership and control. The talk of prior ownership and compensation is not part of what the tribal Aborigines are on about at all.

It was mentioned here that there are saints and sinners among the Aborigines as there are amongst the rest of us. I have been reading bits and pieces about the land council hearings taking place in the Northern Territory at the moment. It seems that the land councils have not taken particular trouble to identify the local traditional owners of areas that are liable to attract royalty benefits from mining and drilling companies. Payments could have been made to the wrong people. Consideration has not been given to the traditional owners as it should have been, but traditional owners are appearing out of the woodwork and approaching the Northern Territory Government and the courts to assert their rights. I think that this is as it should be. I am sorry that they have had the trouble; they should have been able to go through their own land administration. But it is one of the most fruitful developments that we have seen lately-the traditional people are now becoming adapted to our adversary system of law and are using it for their own benefit. If they are capable of doing that and establishing their own areas of land administration where they have authority, this will give us a chance to get rid of those unrepresentative land councils that have no real authority over the traditional Aborigines.

Sacred sites have been referred to as big areas. The ones that I found were not big; in fact, they were quite small. They were about as big as the table in the chamber. A man by the name of Tjuringa is in charge of the sacred sites. Abori-gines have elders. Some are in charge of singing, some are in charge of sacred sites, some are in charge of education and some are in charge of discipline. The man named Tjuringa is in charge of the sacred sites. That is where they have all their carved stones, wood, relics and paraphernalia that is precious to them. They are not gigantic areas, or spheres of influence or any of the other things they have been described as over the years, but these areas are precious to the Aborigines and should be kept.

I notice that a new restructuring of all the departments that have been administering Aboriginal affairs will be put into the one bucket and stirred. One can only hope that the results will be satisfactory. We have had a big debate on this matter in this chamber. I just hope that the encouraging signs that I have mentioned this morning-namely, the ability of our tribal Aborigines to participate in local government and to have successful contact with our legal court system-will not be hurt in any way by this re-organisation and that we can develop and build on those things and not lose the progress that has already been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a short statement on this matter. I think the debate this morning has indicated the success of this policy statement. People with different points of view have all contributed, I think constructively, to this question. It therefore follows that this statement has been successful in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it is worth while analysing just what this statement is. It is a policy statement. It is not a detailed blueprint for action in the future; it is not a text book on Aboriginal affairs; it is not a biography of people deserving praise; it is not a history book; it is not a confession of past wrongs; nor is it a constitutional treatise. It has been approached by different speakers as if it were one or other of those things. Whereas those contributions have been useful, I think they also indicate a misunderstanding of what the policy statement is all about. It is a statement for the future. It is a very hopeful statement. It is a statement which is optimistic, and so it should be, because I think-the debate this morning has indicated this-that there is a determination that the past, which has until recently been a horrible past, shall be redressed in the future and that positive things will flow from it.
I will quickly go through the statement. It is a 20-page document. On the first page it states:
Aboriginal people need to decide for themselves what should be done-not just take whatever governments think or say is the best for them.

Of course, it is in the context that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is to be set up. The Commission will be staffed and run by people who are elected by the Aboriginal community throughout Australia. On page 3 there is the question of the preamble to the enabling Act in which it is stated that the Aboriginals had prior right to the land, having been the occupants of it before non-Aboriginals came to Australia. The preamble itself is set out on page 10, attachment A. It is really a statement of fact. It is important that the facts be stated as to the constitutional impact of statements such as who has owned land in the past. I would have thought that the Act would need to contain something more solemn than simply the preamble to give it constitutional validity. But perhaps that is a matter to discuss later on. In any event, it is very important, as people have conceded here this morning-they have welcomed the statement-that such a statement be made.

On page 4 of the document the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation is discussed. Again, that is something that is long overdue. It flows out of the report of the Miller Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs. It attempts-I have every confidence that the attempt will be successful-to give the Aboriginal people an opportunity to develop an economic basis for their future. Page 5 deals with the Aboriginal land base. That, again, has been discussed quite considerably over the years. On pages 6 and 7 the recent achievements in Aboriginal affairs are discussed. This document is comprehensive, but necessarily short because it is a policy statement. As I say, it is not a text book on Aboriginal affairs. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who has prepared it, on the advice of many, particularly in the Aboriginal community, deserves congratulations and praise. He has been a Minister for only a short time. Although there have been good Ministers in the past, including Senator Peter Baume, who is in the chamber, I can say this about the present Minister: There has not been better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to speak today, but I am moved to do so not by emotion but by the fact that there seems to be some lack of balance in what has been said. I believe that the contributions have been made in a very genuine and sincere way. I would agree with most of what has been said, with some notable exceptions, but it seems to me that a fundamental part of this statement has not been addressed fully. I refer to the dispossession of Aboriginal land by European occupation and the fact that there has been no previous recognition or acknowledgment of their prior ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Cooney said, we seem to spend a lot of our time confessing past wrongs: unless one has the eastern seaboard, middle class social conscience of guilt, one has no compassion, care, empathy or understanding of the Aboriginal community. It seems that the criterion for having some understanding and care for the Aboriginal community is to believe that all their problems can be solved by throwing buckets of money at them and making altruistic statements. We talk about self-determination and then spend the rest of our time telling the Aboriginal community what is good for it.

I want to labour for a moment the question of prior ownership and its legal implications. This statement has been put down by the Labor Government. It seeks to sheet down the question of the legality of prior ownership. The premise is that the contemporary Aboriginal race in Australia has a legal claim to all land in Australia. The debate as put by Mr Hand and by his predecessor, Mr Holding, is not about small pieces of land; it is all about who legally owns Australia. As Mr Hand's statement says, it is the Government's proposal `to acknowledge that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land'. Is that an emotional, altruistic statement, meaning nothing, or is it intended to have consequences? My guess is that it is intended to have consequences-legal consequences.

I am reminded of the submission of the Western Australian branch of the National Aboriginal Conference to the Seaman Aboriginal Land Inquiry set up by the Burke Labor Government in Western Australia to inquire into Aboriginal land rights. It is not without significance that, ultimately, notwithstanding the fact that Seaman brought down recommendations for the granting of very extensive parts of Western Australia to the Aboriginal community, the Government shelved the recommendations. The Western Australian branch of the National Aboriginal Conference had this to say to that inquiry:

The Aboriginal people of Western Australia have sovereign rights to the land through prior ownership and occupation. These rights have never and never will be ceded by them. Accordingly, the aspirations of Aboriginal people with regard to land will not be satisfied until these sovereign rights are addressed and dealt with by legislation.
The submission of the Aboriginal Development Commission to the same inquiry, under the heading `Land Rights-the Philosophy and Purpose', had this to say:
The policies of the Aboriginal Development Commission are based upon the clear recognition of the prior occupation and ownership of the Australian continent by Aboriginal Australians.
The National Aboriginal Conference discussion paper tells us:

It may be argued that the Aboriginal people as a sovereign nation were deprived of the continent of Australia in 1788, and have continued as a sovereign nation who seek the restoration of their lands. This argument is supported by reference to violence perpetrated upon Aboriginal peoples over this period of nearly 200 years, and with the absence of any treaty or agreement concluding the state of war which has continued to exist.
Mr Clyde Holding, the then Minister for Abori-ginal Affairs, told the House of Representatives on 8 December 1983, inter alia:
The prior ownership of Australia by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people must be acknowledged by this Parliament and understood by all Australians.
His motion in the House of Representatives on the same day stated:

The peoples whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of Australia . . . From the time of arrival of representatives of King George III of England and the subsequent conquest of the land and the subjugation of the Aboriginal people, no settlement was concluded between those representatives and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people.
In an address to the Conference on Aboriginal and International Law, Mr Holding said, in part:

That is not to say that Parliament of this country, on behalf of the citizens of this country, cannot recognise the prior ownership by the Aboriginal people of the continent. Nor do I suggest that the conquest of this continent by non-Aboriginal forces should be ignored or disguised as peaceful settlement. Quite the contrary, I hold the strong personal view that unless and until those matters are recognised both on a community basis and by way of formal recognition in the Parliament of Australia, this nation will lack integrity and credibility in the field of human rights in the eyes of its own citizens as well as of the international community. All the policies which my Government are currently pursuing are based firmly on the recognition and acknowledgment of Aboriginal prior ownership and their dispersal and dispossession.

That position is restated in this document. It is understood by most people that these arguments of prior occupation and ownership are not irrelevant to the case for land rights. They are not altruistic, academic statements. The words `occupation' and `ownership' are vital to the legal arguments involved in land rights. They are the basis upon which the land rights activists and, presumably, the draftsmen of this document base their justification for granting land rights to the Aboriginal community.

If it is held that the Aboriginal people had prior ownership of Australia in the legal sense, that in itself has very significant ramifications. Ownership in the legal sense means that there was an Aboriginal nation which had a complete social, economic and political structure. If that proposition is to be accepted, it follows automatically that Australia was not settled or occupied by white people but was invaded. The distinction between occupation or settlement and conquest, as I say, is not purely academic. The difference is particularly significant for land rights.

In the case of conquest, it is generally recognised that privately owned property in a territory which has been acquired by conquest remains unaffected by the transfer of sovereignty, unless or until the new sovereign brings about some alteration in its condition by means of his own domestic law. In the case of occupation or settlement, on the other hand, the basic assumption is that no rights existed at the time of occupation. The question of how sovereignty was acquired is, therefore, directly relevant to the validity of land rights and to compensation for unlawful dispossession or acquisition of private land. It goes without saying that if Australia was terra nullius at the time-in other words, if it was territory belonging to no one or a piece of territory not under the sovereignty of any state-then occupation was by settlement and, if not, by invasion.

The issue of terra nullius does not rest on whether Australia was inhabited but on whether there was an Aboriginal nation with recognisable legislative, executive and judicial organs-in other words, a nation in the proper sense. That is the legal definition of whether a country or territory is terra nullius or is occupied. That is the argument we are confronted with when we look at the legal position in respect of the Aboriginal community. Hence the significance of the comments made by Clyde Holding and the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Their argument is that, prior to white settlement, Australia was occupied by a sovereign nation in the proper sense of the word with a social, political and economic structure and recognisable legislative, executive and judicial organs.

Mr Holding said, in a moment of weakness, that the question of sovereignty is not politically acceptable yet he supports it and goes on to say that Labor policies are based on the premise of prior ownership and of British invasion. He talks about British invasion-that is accepted-which changes the argument about land rights. If one accepts the idea of invasion one accepts, ipso facto, that land rights follow by right and not by need. Notwithstanding that view, that claim has been tested in court on at least two occasions of which I am aware. It was defeated in the Nabalco Pty Ltd case, where the Yolunga people sought to claim prior title at Gove. In the case of Coe v. the Commonwealth, Coe sought the annexation of the eastern coast of Australia, claiming that Captain Cook had not annexed it properly in 1788. Sovereignty means an exclusive and indivisible power and capacity for self-government, together with international recognition of that power.

The Australian Labor Party seems to argue, as do others, that prior to white settlement Aborigines had a sovereign nation. Of course, we have to remember that a sovereign nation refers to people and not to land. We all appreciate that once one puts aside the legal question, the argument for land rights becomes very much subjective, and the wider issues of equity, justice, need and fairness become consequential. The argument becomes a political one and not a legal one. It is important that that be spelt out and put on the record so that we understand the implications, ramifications and, presumably, the reasons that this document tells us that there has been dispossession, that there was prior ownership and prior occupation. If one accepts that in a legal sense, one approaches the question of land rights from a different direction. One ignores and dismisses the question of equity and fairness and, as Senator Chaney said, the granting of land rights on the basis of need and not of right.
There are a couple of other matters that I wish to refer to. Mr Hand, in relation to the compact or understanding, stated:

There is a widely held belief that we cannot come to terms with our history unless we reach some form of compact, agreement, treaty or Makarrata-the name is not significant-between the Aboriginal and Islander and non-Aboriginal people.

I assume that that is Mr Hand's view. His argument is that we must have a compact, a treaty or a makarrata. I am always fascinated when I hear this term `makarrata'. It is not used lightly or by accident. The word `makarrata' is an east Arnhem Land word which means the coming together after a dispute involving the letting of blood or physical violence. When there is a disagreement amongst Aborigines, they have what they call a makarrata; they come together and there is retribution by the letting of blood. So a makarrata is the coming together after the letting of blood and retribution.

On the question of land rights I say this: it ought not be forgotten that those who originally suffered-and there were many-deprivation, cruelty and improper treatment, are no longer alive. That goes back to the time of the Napoleonic wars. I do not mind those in the community who have a social conscience about what their forefathers did. I, for my part, seek to make my judgments about what is good for the Aboriginal community based on their needs now, not on guilt as to what people did at the time of the Battle of Waterloo.

I conclude that point by saying that, in respect of compensation for past losses, the concept remains in modern law, except that it is now called reparation. I thought we learnt something from the Treaty of Versailles, from the First World War, when we had reparation. The Treaty of Versailles instilled a spirit of vengeance and hate. It was put aside in the Second World War because of what happened in the First World War.

It is regrettable that when we have debates of this nature there is inhibition and a lack of frankness. I am sad that people do not have the courage-presumably they do not have the conviction-to debate the real problems that confront the Aboriginal community. Recognition of prior ownership might give a warm inner glow to some in the community, but I do not know what problems it solves. I do not know how it overcomes the problems of alcohol, disease, lack of housing, a general lack of health and a lack of proper education. I do not know how it solves those problems. The clever thing, to show some concern about Aboriginal communities and Aborigines as a whole, is to talk about land rights. There is a great deal to be said about confronting the enormous, debilitating problem that alcoholism is causing the Aboriginal community and the devastation it wreaks not only on children but also on adults.

It is a tragedy that we do not have the courage to debate the question of education. In many white communities in Australia, Aboriginal children are starting school in grade one-working on the premise that their English is as good as that of the white children. We ignore the fact that they start at grade one and end in grade seven, still not being able to speak proper English. We ask ourselves why they leave school illiterate, unqualified, without the capacity for a meaningful job. We put that aside by saying, `They are there; they are equal; they are in the same class'. Rather than having the courage to deal with the problem of their education, we seek to brush it under the carpet and to dismiss it.

We seek to ignore the fact that alcohol, as I said earlier, is causing so much grievous harm and so many problems in the Aboriginal community. Because we feel it would be discriminatory to seek to deal with it in a meaningful way, we ignore it. Anybody who has had anything to do with Aboriginal communities knows that it is the single biggest problem that leads to so many illnesses and problems for the parents and subsequently for the children.

I am sorry that the statement does not give meaningful substance to the intentions of this Government, other than stating that it intends to bring all parts of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs under one roof-presumably, as Senator Peter Baume said, with the intention of Aboriginalising the Department. To damage and destroy organs, such as the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, is, in my view, a major step backwards, having regard to just one contribution that could be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for one thing at least: he identified the crucial issue in the whole debate on Aboriginal affairs, and that is the issue of sovereignty. Australia was not occupied, Australia was not settled, Australia was invaded. Of that there is no doubt. The name of whatever treaty is entered into is significant because what we name the treaty goes to the heart of how we consider the parties involved in the treaty.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to quote from another document which addresses the Foundations for the Future. It is entitled `Aboriginal Sovereign Position and Legal Entitlement for Negotiating a Treaty Under the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties with the Australian ``Government'' in Order to Enshrine Aboriginal Sovereign Rights and Create the Foundations for Black/White Relations in this Land Based on Land, Life, Law, Justice and Peace'. This document was produced by Aboriginal people. I would like to let it speak for itself, if I may. The summary of the document in the preamble is that:

Sovereignty has always inhered in the Aboriginal People of this land now known as `Australia'. From the Beginning, the practice of customary and traditional ownership and possessory right has been held inviolate with the Aboriginal Nations and from these sovereign Rights, all legal and social rights flow.
The preamble goes on to say:

Aboriginal sovereignty still inheres in the Aboriginal People of this land: it has never been extinguished by cession, by treaty, nor by formal purchase, nor by conquest; neither was it acquired by the invaders, the British Australians, by peaceful settlement of an uninhabited land. Our land has been inhabited since the Beginning and resistance to invasion was so aggressive and protracted that the frontier has been described as a line of blood. This resistance has never ceased nor abated to this present day.
In order to enshrine our Sovereign Rights we pursue a Sovereign Treaty under international law with the `Australian Government'.

That is the Aboriginal position which we must address. A compact or a makarrata is not a sovereign treaty because it can be amended by legislation. It is nothing more than a contract between a sovereign group and its subjects. We have to address the question of Aboriginal sovereignty and look to Aboriginal proposals for the settlement of this dispute and for the resolution of this conflict.

Senator Crichton-Browne was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Its report entitled 200 Years Later contains in appendix 1, 24 demands as proposed by the National Aboriginal Conference. I will not read them because time does not allow me to do so. These demands cover self-government, land, the payment of a percentage of gross national income to the Aboriginal people, national parks, the right to art works and artefacts, rights to hunting, the right to all mineral and other resources, the recognition of Aboriginal customary law, Aboriginal schools and freehold title and ownership. In 1983 we had proposals from Aboriginal people as a starting point for the development of some sort of process to deal with Aboriginal sovereignty and the settlement of this conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee report did not recommend a makarrata.
—Senator Crichton-Browne has had enough of a say today.
—Do you mean you cannot answer the question?
—I did not interrupt Senator Crichton-Browne during his address and I resent his interruptions now.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a preoccupation among certain speakers in this debate with the difference between tribal and urban Aboriginal people. There was talk about part Aboriginal people. How is it that we hear everywhere that there are part Aboriginal people but we do not hear of part white people, part Europeans, part Italians or part Greeks? A person's identity is defined by the community to which the person belongs and the community which recognises that person. An Aboriginal person is an Aboriginal person whether he is born and brought up in an urban environment or a traditional tribal environment.

The problem with the statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and the problem with the sort of process that is being addressed here is that they assume a certain structure for the Aboriginal people to organise themselves within. They assume that there is some sort of national body which will deal and negotiate with the Australian Government. The structure of this body is defined by European culture. We are imposing on the Aboriginal people the sort of structure with which we want them to manage their affairs. It seems to me that we need to allow the Aboriginal people the opportunity to develop their own structures coming out of their culture and their traditions and to develop an authentic national Aboriginal system of consultation. From there we should adjust our own cultural and legal frameworks to meet the needs of Aboriginal culture rather than impose our own frameworks upon them.

I wish to give time to Senator Collins. He in this place and his colleague Warren Snowdon in the other place have spoken eloquently and with passion about the Aboriginal people. I wish to hear what Senator Collins has to say. I wish to address the issue of next year which I, quite frankly, would prefer to call 1987A. I would like not to think of there being a 1988. I ask: What are we celebrating? We are celebrating an invasion. We are celebrating rape, murder, torture and theft. As non-Aboriginal people, as a European culture, we are cutting ourselves off from our feelings and our history by denying the reality of history and celebrating a manufactured history, a pretend history, a public relations view of history. The year 1987A, or 1988 if one prefers, should be a year not for celebration but for reflection. It should be a year not for new beginnings but for the carrying through of statements that have been made time and again.

I was here in 1972 when the Aboriginal tent embassy was set up on the front lawns of Parliament House. I saw the Whitlam Government's attempts to do something to bring justice for the Aboriginal people. Time and time again these attempts have stalled and we have had new schemes. What is required is the pursuit of long, protracted, but absolutely necessary negotiations with the sovereign Aboriginal nations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Wood for the courtesy he has shown in curtailing his speech so that I can make a few remarks. Unfortunately, of course, with only 10 minutes to go I will have to trim my sails somewhat. I was going to refer to some of the positive contributions made to this debate this morning by Senators Tambling, Chaney and Childs-and I must say, in particular, the contribution made by Senator Peter Baume. But I do not have time for that. So in the 10 minutes that I have I just want to address a number of issues that underlie the statement. I do so in the full knowledge that this matter inevitably will come back before this chamber before too long, so I am not too concerned about running out of time this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney certainly nailed it down: this document is not a textbook, nor is it a detailed treatise on the administrative structures that will be provided. It is a policy statement. But, with some degree of feeling, I wish to add my voice, even though it has been said before, to the contribution made by Senator Baume this morning. It is quite incorrect to say that this is the first public acknowledgment of the prior ownership of this land by Aboriginal people. The landmark motion moved in the Senate by former Senator Bonner still stands as a very profound statement. Along with a number of others, I regret that, although it was carried unanimously in this chamber, it was never carried in the House of Representatives.

Another point I want to make very quickly is that the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, which was introduced into this Parliament and which has operated since then, has as its very basis the recognition of prior ownership by Aboriginal people. It is indeed the very foundation-stone upon which that Act functions. It is by proving prior ownership before the land commissioner who operates under that Act that Aboriginal people can assert, in the Northern Territory at least, their right to be given crown title to land.

The preamble is an important part of this document. In response to that age old question `What's in a name?' I do not flinch from saying that the answer is, as it has always been, `a great deal'. How could I flinch from saying that when I am on the public record as supporting this makarrata, treaty or otherwise, not only in the Northern Territory Parliament on many occasions but also in this chamber. The name is important because it embodies precisely what it is that we are trying to do.

Senator Baume went over the history of the original treaty which moved to makarrata. Indeed, I have spoken in this chamber previously about some of the misconceptions that surrounded even that name. What we get at the end of the line is important. But I refer honourable senators to what is contained in this document in view of the comment made by Senator Vallentine this morning when, distinguishing the difference between what is contained in this document and Senator Bonner's motion, she said that what is contained in here embodies a legal right rather than a moral right. I just point out to honourable senators that it does precisely the opposite. Page 10 of the document states:
AND WHEREAS they were dispossessed of their land by subsequent European occupation and have no recognised rights over it other than those granted by the Crown;
It may well be that something may appear in the Bill which will follow this preamble at some stage and which may change this situation somewhat; but that is what is in this document.

The question of consultation is important. The fundamental thrust of this document is correct in that it is trying to put decision making back into the hands of Aboriginal people. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has been very specific about his desire to consult broadly on this matter. By doing so I simply assume-I think I have a right to do so-that he will take on board the very hard-nosed-I do not think that is too strong a word-feelings already expressed on this matter by the Aboriginal Development Commission, and indeed the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. They are legitimate Aboriginal points of view and I have no doubt that the Minister will take them on board.

Senator Tambling said a number of things that I wish to discuss as quickly as I can. He said that there is no reference in this document to consultation with non-Aboriginal people. I point out to Senator Tambling that reference to that occurs twice in this document. Both references are to be found on page 4. One is specifically directed to consultation with non-Aboriginal people; the other, a more general reference, talks about refining options put forward by the Australian community for consideration by the Government; so the Minister has taken that on board.

Senator Tambling also made some references to a perception of this body as a black parliament. I would like to disabuse anyone who thinks that is so. It is an unfair comparison because the organisation will be an advisory body-I stress that-to the Minister. It has no more status as an advisory body to the Minister than has any other board set up to do the same sort of work; so, to consider it to be a black parliament is unfair. I have some very strong views on the matter of black parliaments, and I am on the record as putting those views. It is my view that, rather than setting up a black parliament, as the National Aboriginal Conference presumed to be, all major political parties in this country have an absolute obligation instead to do everything in their power to get Aboriginal people into the real parliament rather than setting up some alternative structure. I have to say that I probably have better credentials than anyone else in public life in Australia for asserting that. Hopefully, at some stage we will see Aboriginal people back in the Federal Parliament as they have been-at least in the one isolated case of Senator Bonner-in the past.

I want to make another important point in respect of something Senator Tambling said. He talked about the great powers of this proposed organisation and `the disbursement of very large sums of money'. I assure Senator Tambling that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has no such power; it may well be that there will be some Aboriginal objection to that at some future time. I refer Senator Tambling to two parts of the document to satisfy his puzzled frown. Page 12 states:
The Commission would be responsible for formulation and implementation of general policy, including budgets, subject to the powers of the Minister.
That is not a mistake; it has been very deliberately put in there and in fact is expanded upon at page 18 which, again relating to powers, states:
. . . in the light of regional priorities, develop budgetary proposals for the Minister's approval.

It will in fact advise the Minister on budgets. It will set priorities, but-I refer Senator Tambling to the document-the disbursements of money under these arrangements will be made, as they are now, by the responsible Minister.

Senator Tambling made a reference to nepotism and his fear that Aboriginal people will use this organisation to accommodate their relatives. I have some feelings about this. That may well happen. But nepotism is not a personal trait confined exclusively to Aboriginal people. I know of some members of this Parliament who have employed their wives and indeed their children in their electorate offices-so nepotism is hardly a fault that can be confined exclusively to Aboriginal people.

I wish to finish on the question of zones because I have made representations to the Minister about them, as has the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon. I will conclude, unfortunately early, by saying that I share the concerns that have been raised by a number of honourable senators in this House this morning about the unworkability of the current draft-that is all it is-arrangement of the zones that have been provided in the maps attached to this document. I believe that some of them are unworkable. But the Minister has assured me that he is flexible on this matter and will act on representations made to him from across Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORMER MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Did the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories at any stage discuss with the Prime Minister, or any of the Prime Minister's senior advisers, the tender process for the theatre complex for Australia's World Expo pavilion? If so, when did any such conversation or conversations occur? Further, what was the extent of the involvement of the Prime Minister, and/or his office, in the tender process? Finally, if the Minister is still in a state of blissful ignorance, will he ascertain the facts and advise the Senate as soon as possible?

—Senator Chaney refers to my state of blissful ignorance. I am quite happy to accept blissful ignorance about a matter which has unduly excited him but has not unduly excited me, if I might say so, in the terms in which he puts it.
—It caused the resignation of one of your colleagues.
—Look, I understand Senator Chaney's view of the world. I will just give him mine, if he does not mind.
—We are a bit of a crosspatch today, are we?
—Yes, I am a crosspatch today. It is not difficult to be a crosspatch when one has to listen to some of Senator Chaney's parsimonious views of the world.
—Parsimonious? I do not think you know what it means.
—Of course I know what it means; it means stingy minded, lest there be any doubt about that.
—Not stingy minded; just stingy.

—If Senator Chaney wants to be a pedagogue I suggest he go back to school; he would be very good at it there. I am sure, of course, that the Prime Minister had discussions with Mr Brown at various stages about the theatre project for the World Expo in Brisbane. I am sure that many of the discussions-if there were many-would have taken place not in any formal sense but in exchanges which normally occur between Ministers about various matters. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's concession-which seems to be based just on surmise on his part-that the Prime Minister would have had discussions with Mr Brown, will he ascertain what conversations did occur and the extent to which the Prime Minister, and/or his office, were involved in the tender process-a process which has been clearly shown to have been defective in a whole series of particulars?
—I am quite able to say that the Prime Minister was not involved in the tender process.
—That is not the question.
—I beg the honourable senator's pardon. Senator Chaney just asked me: Was the Prime Minister involved in the tender--
—I said: Were there conversations about the tender process?

—Well, I am not sure that that is the way the honourable senator put it. But let me say that the Prime Minister was not involved in the tender process. Also, insofar as the tender process may have involved reports from the relevant committee, yes, I am sure Mr Brown would have had discussions with the Prime Minister about those matters-but discussions of the kind to which I referred in the earlier part of my answer; namely, not in any strictly formal sense, but discussions which are a normal part of discourse and interchange between Ministers about various matters affecting their portfolios.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER COMMUNITY HEALTH SERVICE: JOB ADVERTISEMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the Minister aware that the Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service placed an advertisement in the Courier-Mail of Saturday, 28 November 1987, calling for an `Aboriginal hospital liaison officer'? Is the Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service federally funded? Did the advertisement stipulate that the position was to be filled by a person of Aboriginal or Islander descent? Were people who inquired about this position advised that it was in fact a condition of employment that the applicant had to be an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander? If this was the case-that is, that non-Aboriginals and non-Islanders were excluded from consideration for the position-is this action a breach of the Racial Discrimination Act or any other Federal Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston did give me some notice of this question, which enables me to answer that, yes, I am aware that an advertisement was placed by the Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service on 28 November 1987 for an Aboriginal hospital liaison officer. The Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service is federally funded. The advertisement did not stipulate that the position was to be filled by a person of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander descent. One of the qualifications was that applicants must relate well with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Inquiries made of the Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service indicate that people who inquired about the position were informed that it was in fact intended for Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders. An apology was offered to callers who felt that the advertisement was misleading.

ANSWER.PARA: It is open to any person who feels that he or she has been discriminated against to complain to the Race Discrimination Commissioner under the Racial Discrimination Act or to the Human Rights Commissioner under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. Inquiries made of the commissions indicate that no such complaints have yet been made. If a complaint were made under the Racial Discrimination Act, one issue that would need to be considered would be whether action taken by the Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service amounted to what is termed `a special measure' taken for the sole purpose of advancement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, as permitted by the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. But as to the question of whether in fact there has been any breach of the law, of course that involves formulating a legal opinion based on the facts and I will not offer such an opinion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORMER MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface my question by saying that I hope the Minister is today better informed on the misleading of Parliament by former Minister John Brown than he was yesterday when he claimed, quite incredibly, not to have been aware of the front page news report in the Sydney Morning Herald. I ask: Why was no action taken by the Government to correct the serious misleading of the Parliament by former Minister Brown when obviously a number of people in the Minister's Department or his personal office, and perhaps even other Ministers' offices, must have known that he had given wrong information to the House of Representatives? Why was it only after the matter became public in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald that the Government addressed this most serious issue? Finally, did the Prime Minister take action following the censure motion against Mr Brown last week to assure himself that the account given by one of his most senior Ministers was correct?

—The misleading of Parliament by Minister Brown on 10 December was first drawn to the Prime Minister's attention yesterday. It was first drawn to my attention yesterday, somewhat more slowly, I presume, because I was not made aware of it in the morning. Minister Brown, even as at the time of his resignation, believed, and still believes, that he did not wilfully mislead the Parliament about his understanding of the set of circumstances. That was his position last night, and it still is. It is quite clear that whatever the Minister's state of mind about his belief at the time he spoke in Parliament, on 10 December and earlier, there was clear evidence of a set of circumstances which was different from the Minister's understanding of the matter. I am asked why Ministers in the Government were not aware of Mr Brown misleading Parliament on 10 December, as it is alleged, until 17 December. I remind the House of how the parliamentary process works. There was not much evidence that anybody in the Opposition was aware of it until yesterday, either.
—We did not have the facts. We did not have the information.
—We did not have the information either.
—You did not try to find out. Do you think Fraser would not have gone looking for information after the censure motion?

—I do not know. Fraser might have gone looking for anything-maybe his trousers. I do not know what Mr Fraser might have done. Ministers do not, in this Government, or in any government, spend all their time reading speeches by other Ministers and checking their veracity or otherwise. If we did, we would be doing nothing else. We are very busy doing things which are important.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Setting aside as an irrelevance the well-known fact of the slower reflexes of the Leader of the Government in the Senate and that he did not hear what went on on AM or in the Sydney Morning Herald, I still ask the final question again: Are there no procedures in place in this Government so that when the most serious of charges are laid, leading to a censure motion, a follow-up is made to see whether there is any substance to them?

—The censure motion, I remind Senator MacGibbon, was not about misleading Parliament. It was in the censure motion debate that the alleged misleading of Parliament arose. The misleading of Parliament is an event subsequent to the censure motion. Insofar as the honourable senator wanted a personal explanation of what I was doing instead of listening to AM, I was, in fact, running around the Canberra lake at that time of the morning. It is something I do every morning. I do not regard it as an act of crass political irresponsibility not to listen to the AM program. Subsequent to running around the lake, I was engaged in a series of meetings all morning until I came to Question Time. I was not engaged in a series of meeting which gave other Ministers or members of my staff access to me at that time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to an article in yesterday's Daily Telegraph regarding the annual report of the Defence Force Ombudsman and in particular to a reference to the case of a former Army sergeant's claim to have eight years of her enlistment included as a qualifying period for long service leave after having a break in service longer than the 12 months permissible for maintaining continuity of entitlements. Can the Minister explain why he did not make an act of grace payment effectively facilitating the reinstatement of entitlements which would be attached to continuity of service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article. Let me state the facts of the case. A member of the Defence Force, specifically of the Army, took a discharge and later sought to re-enlist. The Act provides that such a person must be re-enlisted within 12 months of the resignation in order to have the prior service counted for long service leave purposes. In this case, the re-enlistment was not completed within 12 months. The application for re-enlistment was lodged within 12 months but it was not processed. The basis for the claim-spurious though it is-that I should have used my powers under the Audit Act to grant an act of grace payment equivalent to the long service leave forgone rests on the fact that the application was lodged within 12 months but the re-enlistment procedures were not completed within the 12 months.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe that the Commonwealth has any obligation to retrospectively arrange people's affairs in such a manner as will maximise benefits in accordance with the options they had available at a particular time but did not at that time pursue. I make absolutely no apology for my decision. Indeed, for me to do otherwise, to capriciously, subjectively or arbitrarily-however you like to put it-overrule a provision of the Act that re-enlistment must occur within 12 months, would be an erosion of the rule of law. I am surprised that people who regard themselves as conservatives cannot see that. It would be an erosion of the rule of law because the Act lays down conditions under which certain entitlements will accrue. It would be, I believe, quite wrong for me to overrule that.

Returning to the justification-spurious though it is-cited in support of this claim: it rests, as I said, on the fact that the application was received within 12 months but was not processed. If it is to be accepted that that is a valid justification, let me cite another possible example. I determined, three weeks ago today, I think it was, that the exit rate for the Commonwealth superannuation scheme employee contributions for the September quarter and up to 20 October would be zero. I have no doubt that people would have submitted their resignation applications the day before I did that, or the week before it, and those resignation applications would not have been processed. Not even an ombudsman, or a former ombudsman, I would expect, would believe that the Commonwealth should instantly process all applications which come before it. It is not practicable to do that.

To return to the case of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, no doubt such applications were received but not processed. The people affected by that could quite easily lose amounts of $8,000 to $10,000 because of it. I have absolutely no intention of using my act of grace powers to compensate those people for not having put their applications or resignations in early enough to have had them processed by Friday, 26 November, or whenever it was. As this is a very important point I will repeat it. Not only will I make absolutely no apology for the decision I took; for me to have done otherwise would have been to use my authority under the Audit Act to effectively overturn a section of an Act of Parliament. I regard that as an erosion of the rule of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in a Christmassy spirit of good will and genuine helpfulness that seems to be somewhat lacking around here at the moment. Given that two Opposition senators were given leave to have their speeches on the fishing Bills incorporated in Hansard last night, thereby speeding up proceedings considerably, does the Minister believe, firstly, that standing order 406, which prohibits the reading of speeches, is now essentially meaningless; secondly, that in the interests of saving taxpayers' money, Australia should institute a system of parliament by post, in which legislation is tabled and interested-or even disinterested, not to say the occasionally uninterested-members of parliament can forward their speeches by mail to the Clerk for incorporation in Hansard, thereby not having to interrupt important electorate duties, or overseas travel arrangements in the case of Senator Hill; thirdly, that the committee stage debate should be conducted via senators' and members' and Ministers' fax machines, thereby increasing the profits of Telecom Australia so that time charged calls would not need to be increased; fourthly, that debates on matters of public importance and urgency motions should be conducted via Australian Broadcasting Corporation video link to the electorate offices of members of parliament, unless the Minister considers that this would prove ultimately the undesirability of televising Parliament; and finally, that questions without notice should be placed on notice on the grounds that most of them already are and that most are not answered anyway, so the current situation would continue in its normal fashion?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I understand that Standing Orders prohibit a question being asked which is a reflection on the decision of the Senate. The Senate having decided to grant leave yesterday for certain speeches to be incorporated, I put it to you that the question is out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MacGibbon

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order, I ask you to apply standing order 438, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) persistently and willfully obstructs the business of the Senate-

This leads on to other charges. My basis for asking you to apply that standing order is the fact that the Australian Democrats, on reading the division lists for this session of the Parliament, found that the score was not high enough to demonstrate their independence. So, at seven minutes a time for a division, we had probably 20 or 30 unnecessary divisions during which the Democrats sat on one side of the chamber and the Liberal, National and Labor parties sat on the other side. The good order and the conduct of the Senate were thereby infringed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. In the spirit of Christmas, I will allow the question, in the way in which it was asked, to be answered. I ask the Minister to deal with those areas in the question which are within his area of responsibility.

—Mr President, I take another point of order. Is it not the case that when leave is sought for a speech to be incorporated it can be refused by any single senator, including Senator Haines? Therefore, on the evidence that leave was granted, Senator Haines obviously gave leave for the incorporation of those speeches.
—Order! That is not a point of order; it is a matter of fact.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question asked by the Leader of the Australian Democrats was directed at me. I think if she reads the Hansard she will find that Senator Macklin asked me to incorporate my speech. A check on the Hansard--
—Order! There is no point of order but the honourable senator has made his point. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the points of order and the discussion have been so scintillating that I have forgotten the original question. But I remember sufficient of it at least to hazard a guess that it is directed at me in my capacity as the Minister responsible for technology. One of the things which societies such as ours have to confront is that with advancing technology a number of professions become redundant. It is very difficult to explain to people in the community that they have to adjust and take new steps to fulfil their life-paths because of the onslaught of new technology which renders them increasingly irrelevant.
—That is why you have taken up running around the lake, is it?

—It is one of the reasons. In fact, Senator Puplick, who is probably more astute about these matters than are most members of the Opposition-if I may say so, that is not saying very much-would understand the expression `high touch'. Running around the lake is a high touch activity as distinct from a high tech activity-that is to say, it is a reaction to high technology which leads people into different forms of activity. I suppose being here is a high touch activity; it is certainly not high tech.

ANSWER.PARA: There is much point in Senator Haines's question. I often ask myself why politicians, including me, invited to speak at various functions do not send a brochure instead of going themselves. I know exactly what Senator Boswell is going to say every time he makes a speech. I like to think that I divert him somewhat. He always attacks me when I walk into the chamber and I think that is the sort of digression which is useful and entertaining and all that sort of stuff. I could devise a brochure for Senator Boswell which could be handed around to all honourable senators. We know exactly what he would have said if he had been here. I am not picking on Senator Boswell; it is just that he made the last point of order. It was the only memorable one and he is the only person whom I remember.

But there is a lot of point in Senator Haines's question. I suppose from time to time the Standing Orders Committee tries to grapple with these issues. I say, as a member of that Committee, that, except for the Clerks, who probably make some more sensible input, we are probably total failures. I cannot help Senator Haines with many of the other aspects of her question. I would like to think about them over the Christmas vacation, but I assure her that I am not going to because I intend to enjoy myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. Yesterday, I believe, your attention was drawn to the report in Wednesday's Sydney Morning Herald about overweight politicians and senior public servants in New South Wales. Is it proposed to prepare an overall summary of the results of all the heart risk and weight tests carried out on honourable members and honourable senators earlier in this session in this place, which were arranged by the Parliament House authorities? Would it be considered appropriate to release the summary results of those heart risk tests, with a view to demonstrating clearly that Federal parliamentarians, by comparison with their New South Wales counterparts, are increasingly `trim, taut and terrific'?

—As in previous years, the National Heart Foundation is preparing a report on the annual heart risk evaluation program for parliamentarians. Copies of the reports are made available to all the participants. These reports do not include information on individual assessments but do contain trend analysis. I am advised that, on the basis of these studies, Federal parliamentarians are healthier than their State counterparts, although looking around this chamber I have some doubts as to whether this would apply today.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. What discussions did the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories have with Qantas Airways Ltd, Ministers, or anyone else about possible sponsorship by Qantas of the theatre project at the Australian pavilion at the Brisbane World Expo? Did the Minister ever attempt to use the promise of Qantas financial support, conditional on Bob Rogers winning the contract, and in advance of any formal decision by the Qantas Board, to help him get his-expletive deleted-way and to ensure that Mr Rogers was successful?

—Yesterday I was asked a series of questions on this matter by Senators Puplick and Chaney. They primarily concerned the second committee and I therefore spent a great deal of time yesterday afternoon looking at those documents in terms of whether or not former Minister Brown had misled the House. I indicated this morning that I would be prepared to answer the questions that were asked of me yesterday. I am not fully aware of conversations that Mr Brown had with Qantas because they were not germane to the discussions that we had last night. If the honourable senator requires further information about that, I will certainly attempt to answer his queries for him. I cannot at the moment.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald reporting the Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, contradicting Senator Stone by making it clear that the Opposition will be examining consumption tax proposals? Does the Government welcome the Opposition's acceptance of the need to fund its tax cut proposals, as indicated by this change of attitude? What are the reasons for the Government not seeking to broaden the tax base in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Sydney Morning Herald report, the most important section of which quotes Mr Howard as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: We will be examining all funding options, including a consumption tax . . .
He was asked:
In spite of what Senator Stone said?
He replied:
In spite of what anyone says.

He went on from that. In one sense I welcome this somewhat belated recognition by the Opposition Leader that there would be a need for an alternative tax if income tax rates were to be cut to the extent that he was talking about, that there must be some alternative tax that would raise many billions of dollars in revenue. Naturally, I welcome his belated, implicit recognition of that fact and the small step towards fiscal responsibility which he has taken in acknowledging that. My fear, however, is that when the crunch comes at some time in the future Mr Howard will do what he did in the past; that is, cave in to the National Party in Queensland, instead of going to Brisbane to grovel before the former Premier of Queensland, he will go there to grovel to Senator Stone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is losing the Christmas spirit altogether. I ask the Minister to withdraw that.

—Very well, I will withdraw it. I was also asked why the Government did not proceed with that type of tax measure. There were a number of reasons, but I think everybody would agree that the principal reason was the possible inflationary consequences. The broad-based consumption tax, which the Government looked at just over two years ago, would have increased the consumer price index (CPI) by 6 1/2 percentage points. That would have been much less of a problem if the CPI effect of that could have been quarantined from wage demands and wage outcomes. It appeared at the time that it was highly unlikely that that could have happened. So instead of there being a 6 1/2 per cent blip in the inflation rate, we would very likely have moved to a new plateau 6 1/2 per cent higher than the one that existed before. That, by general agreement, was the principal reason that the Government did not proceed with that measure.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE SITE: SEVERANCE PAY

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations noted reports that the pace-setting severance pay agreement, now ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, for approximately 1,000 building workers on the new Parliament House will add a further $1m to the cost of the project?
