Does the determination `conform to the Government's social security, taxation and wage-fixing principles' which were stated by the Minister here on 7 October as a requirement for favourable consideration as a severance pay scheme which at that time he said required substantial amendment if it was either to meet its intended objectives or to satisfy Government wages policy or conciliation and arbitration principles? I ask the Minister: What substantial changes have taken place since October 7 to make this scheme acceptable, if it is now acceptable, and what will the costs and other consequences be of this decision being spread through the building industry?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: TRANSPORT OF ANIMALS

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister representing the Minister for Defence state whether or not Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Hercules planes were used to transport Diana and Congo, two West African pygmy hippopotami, from the Melbourne Zoo to Broome in north Western Australia to a private zoo owned by the British developer, Lord MacAlpine? If so, what were the terms and conditions, including costs to the Australian taxpayer, of this excess baggage? Will this service be made available to Lord MacAlpine for the purpose of transporting his British hybrid cattle to his lease at Walcott Inlet in remote north Western Australia, which he has obtained for cattle breeding and tourism development inside a proposed national park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had this matter investigated. The first hint that there may be some truth to Senator Vallentine's question came with an examination of the flight catering manifest, which contained a provision for four hundredweight of swamp weed, 200 gallons of Yarra River water, eight dozen cream buns and a bucket and shovel. There is no truth to the allegation that the RAAF was tricked into carrying the abovementioned Congo and Diana in the belief that they were two nuclear disarmament senators. It is true, however, that two pygmy hippopotami were transported on an RAAF C130 Hercules aircraft from Melbourne to Broome on 5 and 6 December 1987. The aircraft in question was tasked on duties associated with an RAAF team of personnel engaged on adventure training in the north-west, involving the recovery of a World War II Spitfire aircraft from the Prince Regent River. No additional costs were involved in the activity and no charges were levied.

ANSWER.PARA: The background to the approval by the Chief of the Air Staff is that Lord MacAlpine had been of immeasurable assistance to the RAAF team in its recovery operations in providing the use of a barge from which to mount the operation. The use of an already scheduled RAAF aircraft to convey the animals in question represented an opportunity to respond appropriately to the assistance, at no cost to the Commonwealth. There is no intention to offer similar assistance to Lord MacAlpine in relation to any other activity, nor has any such request been received. For background purposes, it is advised that the RAAF team successfully recovered the Spitfire, on behalf of the RAAF museum. The team operated in the most arduous conditions and the success of the operation was due in no small measure to the large degree of assistance and good will shown by the people of the north-west.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Treasurer will be aware that a recent Auditor-General's report found that there were significant deficiencies in the procedures of the Australian Taxation Office to combat tax avoidance by international profit-shifting practices. How does the Minister account for the failure of the Australian Taxation Office to improve its international auditing effort, as there had been an acknowledgment for some years of the huge loss to tax revenue through profit shifting? Can the Minister give the Senate an estimate of the cost to Australian revenue of overseas profit-shifting arrangements? If not, will the Australian Taxation Office be initiating a comprehensive assessment of the cost to Australia of this tax evasion, as the Auditor-General recommended?

—I am, in general, aware of the substance of the Auditor-General's criticism, but I do not recall it in any detail. Frequently, however, when such criticisms are made, they refer to a period two or even three years ago-and there could have been significant changes in the meantime. Indeed, since this Government came into office the Taxation Office has been provided with a very substantial increase in staff and other resources, unlike the record of the previous Government, which kept running down the resources available to the Tax Office to make life easier for tax evaders and tax avoiders. There certainly have been cases-but that may not be applicable in this instance-where the Auditor-General's criticisms have been, to say the least, drawing a rather long bow in the attempt at quantification. I cannot give Senator Watson an estimate of how much tax may be avoided or evaded in the way he suggests. I am not sure whether anybody could give anything that reasonably could be called an estimate. I would expect it to be more like a guess. However, I will refer the question to the Treasurer to see whether any more definitive information can be made available.
—I address my question to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts.
—Are you Congo or Diana?

—I am not quite sure whether I am Congo or Diana. Is the drilling work which Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has recently admitted to conducting outside the Coronation Hill lease in Kakadu National Park being done with the approval of the Government? If not, what action will the Government take to halt these activities?

—The work done by BHP in recent times has been done with the approval of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and it has involved, as examples, some drilling for looking at the tailing stand for the purposes of an environmental impact statement and some road alignments. As to the claim made by the Wilderness Society in recent days that work is being done outside the project area without permission, as far as I have been able to ascertain that is incorrect.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the declaration of the rainforests of north Queensland as part of the World Heritage drastically changed the guidelines for the construction of the new Parliament House? Does it mean that, as from 11 August 1987, timbers from the rainforests will no longer be acceptable? Does this mean that a team of public servants has been involved and is now involved in deciding which timber is acceptable-that is, that provided before 11 August is acceptable but that provided after that date is not acceptable? Is exactly the same timber capable of being good timber or bad timber purely as a result of the date on which it was logged? How is timber which was felled before 11 August 1987, but dressed to satisfy the Parliament House Construction Authority tender in a factory subsequent to that date, to be treated? What is the Authority's position on legally binding contracts for rainforest timber when the Authority now reneges on accepting delivery? If the additional cost is not an estimated $10m to $15m, what is the extra cost and how will it be determined? Does the Minister not think that this situation is absolutely stupid and shows a lack of consultation with the Government?

—I rarely put on record my views of what is absolutely stupid, or whether a question is particularly wooden, but that contains a substantial degree of detail and I can assist Senator Boswell only by putting it on notice and giving him an answer in the new session, although the matter has been on the public record in terms of the Government's attitude to the use of rainforest timber in the new Parliament House. This has received a fair bit of publicity and has been referred to in the various reports of the Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. As to some of those details on costing and other opinions sought by Senator Boswell, I will have to seek some advice from portfolio Minister West and provide that information later.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: WILLIAMTOWN BASE PLANS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a media report yesterday that plans for the Royal Australian Air Force's Williamtown base were found on a pavement in Elizabeth Street, Sydney, by a passerby? Is the media information as outlined on page 3 of yesterday's Brisbane Courier-Mail accurate and, if so, can the Minister explain how this event came to take place? Has any inquiry been set up, or is any inquiry envisaged, to identify obvious security breaches involved and the names of those people responsible? What, if any, was the potential threat to national security with the loss of these plans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to that article. I am informed of the following, which may assist Senator Jones. Resulting from media inquiries regarding the finding of the sketch plans of the RAAF base at Williamtown by a member of the public in Elizabeth Street, Redfern on 16 December 1987, RAAF police began an immediate investigation into the circumstances and consequences of the discovery. The investigation revealed that the plans were 1982 conceptual sketch plans of various domestic and unclassified operational facilities and contained no information that could be regarded as having any security significance. Further inquiries indicate that the construction plans had possibly been discarded by Department of Housing and Construction (DHC) staff as part of a general waste disposal exercise at their construction office at Elizabeth Street, Redfern.

ANSWER.PARA: The documents are unclassified and are representative of the type of documentation openly available to the public contractors as part of the normal tendering processes for Government construction projects. Firms and individuals interested in submitting tenders for construction projects have to have access to such documentation to decide whether they are interested in tendering for such projects and, if so, for the necessary preparation of the tender. Such tendering processes are handled by the DHC on behalf of the Department of Defence.

On the other hand, I am advised that any defence construction projects which have security implications-for example, the need to protect sensitive defence capability or involving construction details of sensitive installations including security arrangements-are, as a matter of course, given security classifications. They are handled using quite different procedures which ensure that only those with a need to know have access, and availability is restricted to firms that have cleared facility status. The documents found yesterday do not fall into that category. Further investigation by the Department of Defence is therefore considered not to be warranted and the documents have been returned to the Department of Housing and Construction authorities. That Department is, I understand, conducting further inquiries on its own behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that a hearing date for the second tier wage claim for the defence forces has already been delayed twice, and is now set down for Wednesday, 23 December. I also draw the Minister's attention to the widespread dissatisfaction in the defence forces over pay and conditions. It is a fact that the Armed Forces Federation has telexed the Minister, Mr Willis, asking for his assurance that his Department will have reached agreement on a second tier package in time to meet the hearing date next Wednesday? Is it also a fact that, if the date is not met, the hearing will be delayed well into January? Will the Minister assure the Senate and the defence forces that the Government will be ready to proceed to a final hearing next Wednesday?

—The briefing that I have on this matter is not as up to date as Senator Newman is, but I will try to get an answer this afternoon. I understand the point of the question clearly and, as I understand it, negotiations have been proceeding satisfactorily, but I had better get a full report on them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I refer him to the mining activities presently being undertaken at the Mount Etna limestone caves in central Queensland. Does the Minister accept that there is a need to protect and preserve the limestone caves and the world famous Bat Cleft and its associated wildlife? Is the Minister aware of the advice tendered to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by Sir Maurice Byers, QC, in which he stated that the Commonwealth had the opportunity, under the corporations power of the Constitution, to control the trading activities of mining companies and, therefore, by extension to halt the vandalism occurring at Mount Etna? If not, will he give an undertaking to the Senate that he will examine the Byers option and report back to this chamber on the possibility of using such powers to protect Mount Etna and its associated wildlife?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of mining activities at Mount Etna. I think that they are not necessarily a recent feature of the landscape. They have been going on for some time. The significance of the caves is well and truly established and I know that they provide habitat conditions for cave animals, particularly the endangered ghost bats and the bent-wing bats. Over several years, conservationists have expressed their concerns to successive Commonwealth governments about limestone mining at Mount Etna. The caves are listed on the Register of the National Estate. While that is laudable, of course it does not impose any legal constraint on an owner of private property. DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE HUMAN EMBRYO EXPERIMENTATION BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement responding to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 and the report of the Family Law Council entitled Creating Children, and I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE HUMAN EMBRYO EXPERIMENTATION BILL 1985 AND THE REPORT OF THE FAMILY LAW COUNCIL ``CREATING CHILDREN''

I am today responding on behalf of the Government to two important reports which have contributed significantly to the issues facing the Australian community in the emerging area of reproductive technology. These reports are:
(a) The report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 of October 1986 entitled ``Human Embryo Experimentation in Australia''.
(b) The report of the Family Law Council of August 1985 entitled ``Creating Children: A Uniform Approach to the Law and Practice of Reproductive Technology in Australia''.
SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE HUMAN EMBRYO EXPERIMENTATION BILL REPORT

2. The Senate Select Committee was established in October 1985 following Senate debate on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 brought forward by Senator Harradine. The terms of reference of the Committee required it to examine the need for research on embryos in the context of the In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) programs, the necessity for guidelines for research, and the Bill's proposals for certain research to be prohibited.

3. Senator Harradine's Bill proposed prohibitions on human embryo experimentation, criminal penalties for such experimentation and allowed for injunctions to be sought restraining institutions or persons from engaging in experimentation. During the debate on the Bill there was concern expressed that the injunction procedure, together with the imposition of criminal penalties, would bring about the cessation in Australia of research relating to IVF.

4. The Senate Committee reported in October 1986 (Senate Hansard p 970). The Committee was not unanimous in its recommendations, presenting majority and minority reports, with Senator Harradine joining the majority subject to certain qualifying comments.

5. The majority of the Committee pointed to a distinction between ``therapeutic experimentation'' which was defined as experimentation with diagnostic or curative value for the embryo concerned and ``non-therapeutic experimentation'' with no such value but undertaken to advance medical and scientific knowledge.

6. They concluded that the respect due to the embryo from the process of fertilization onwards required its protection from destructive non-therapeutic experimentation. Therapeutic experimentation would, however, be permitted.

7. The majority saw no ``marker'' event in the development of the embryo as being significant in determining the respect to apply and recommended that a concept of ``guardianship'' be adopted as the most appropriate model for protection of the status of the embryo. They also did not allow any distinction between so called ``spare'' embryos and those which might be created for experimental purposes.

8. The majority of the Committee found inadequate the present system of regulation of IVF research through Institutional Ethics Committees established in individual institutions giving voluntary adherence to the nationality promulgated guidelines of the Medical Research Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. They favoured a co-operative legislative approach by Federal and State legislatures in which accredited institutions would need to seek a research licence from a national body prior to research being carried out. In considering proposals for the licensing of research the national body would need to act consistently with proposed Commonwealth legislation. That legislation would include a broad declaration of principle supporting the creative aspects of reproductive technology but making unlawful any destructive non-therapeutic experimentation which frustrated the development of the human embryo.

9. In other words rather than the prohibition model put forward by Senator Harradine in his Bill the majority of the Select Committee proposed an accreditation and licensing system based on national legislation and with a national regulatory body.

10. The minority of the Senate Committee took a different approach which did not involve a prohibition on experimentation but proposed that the decision makers in relation to the embryo be the gamete donors and/or the woman in whose uterus the embryo is to be placed. These decision makers would be able to make all decisions about their embryo, including the type of research which might be undertaken, taking into account a requirement that full and proper advice and information be given to them prior to and during their time on an IVF program.

11. The minority also accepted the proposal that there be a national body to establish guidelines and examine research protocols to ensure they conform with the guidelines and to recommend licensing of research institutes and programs. The minority recommended broad community representation as part of this national body to foster continuing debate and to take account of new developments in medical and scientific endeavour in the field of reproductive technology.
FAMILY LAW COUNCIL REPORT

12. In February 1984 the Family Law Council established a sub-committee under the Chairmanship of Mr Justice Asche, now Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory, to report on the issues raised by reproductive technology. The report of the Council entitled ``Creating Children'', was tabled in Parliament on 21 August 1985.

13. The principal recommendation of the Family Law Council was that there should be a national approach to the range of issues arising out of reproductive technology and that a National Council on Reproductive Technology, a multi-disciplinary body with lay representation, should be established to advise Commonwealth and State Governments on matters relating to reproductive technology.

14. Some of the issues considered by the Family Law Council and for which it saw value in examination by its proposed National Council included a review of State and Territory laws on the status of children born of donor gametes; questions of counselling and keeping of records; surrogacy; use of donor gametes in reproductive technology; the allocation of health care funds; commercial exploitation of reproductive technology and human embryo experimentation.

15. The Family Law Council also touched upon the issue of human embryo experimentation, and its regulation, which was the focus of the Senate Committee Report. It recommended that the production of human embryos for the sole purpose of research or experimentation should be prohibited and, by a majority opinion, that research or experimentation on `spare' embryos from an IVF program should also be prohibited. The Council recognised that the issue of embryo research was a contentious one, that should be taken up by its proposed National Council on Reproductive Technology.
ISSUES
16. The Government recognises that the matters dealt with in these two reports are profound and complex. They raise fundamental questions of the nature of life and of the values of society.
17. The issues will not go away-indeed the expansion and development of biomedical knowledge and technology will continue to raise new challenges and dilemmas equally as difficult in the future.

18. As identified in the reports of the Senate Select Committee and the Family Law Council there are a large number of sometimes competing interests which need to be taken into account in developing social policies for reproductive technology. Included in these are the interests of the infertile, the interests of embryonic life, the interests of medical researchers and persons suffering from diseases which may be assisted by research on embryos, and the interests of women. There are also differing and conflicting views within the community over the social and ethical issues raised by the IVF program generally and by embryo experimentation in particular. These differing and conflicting views can be expected to apply to other areas likely to be affected by science and technology in the future.
19. The Government, in responding to these two reports, has considered the principal issues they raise. These issues are:-
(a) whether destructive non-therapeutic embryo experimentation should be prohibited by legislation;
(b) whether there should be legislative regulation of IVF practice and research and, if so, what form that regulation should take; and
(c) whether a national body on reproductive technology should be established and, if so, what the functions and role of that body should be.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

PROCTEXT.PARA: 20. As recommended by both the Family Law Council and Senate Committee reports, the Government has consulted with the States and Territories through the Australian Health Ministers' Conference and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. The States are not inclined to support a uniform prohibitive approach, preferring a consultative body with responsibilities for providing advice to governments on the full range of issues arising from reproductive technology.

21. All States have commissioned reports from broadly based commissions of inquiry into issues related to the practice of artificial conception. Only New South Wales has not yet received a report for Government consideration. Victoria has passed legislation to give effect to the report that it has received. South Australia recently introduced a Bill to give effect to its Government Report.
22. I will now outline the current States' approach to the main issues raised by the reports.

23. In Victoria, the Waller Committee reported in 1983 and 1984; its recommendations have been substantially implemented by the enactment of the Infertility (Medical Procedures) Act 1984, not all Parts of which have yet been proclaimed to commence operation. That Act prohibits research procedures which would result in damage to the embryo except where it has been approved by a Standing Review and Advisory Committee established under the Act. IVF practice and research is also confined by the Act to institutions licensed by the Committee. The Waller Report recommended, by majority, that embryo experimentation should be limited to spare embryos produced during an IVF program. More recently, Victoria passed further amendments which will allow for scientific experimentation on pre-syngamous embryos in limited circumstances.

24. In Queensland, the Demack Committee reported in March 1984. The Committee recommended that a State body be established to develop ethical guidelines for research into human reproduction and that IVF and embryo transfer should only be performed at centres licensed by the Director-General of Health for that State. The Queensland Government has so far only agreed to the recommendations to regularise the legal status of children born as a result of IVF or embryo transfer.

25. In Tasmania, the Chalmers Committee reported in June 1985. While recommending that research and experimentation on human embryos was not acceptable to community standards in Tasmania, the Chalmers Report recommended that decisions on this issue should be taken at a national level. The Chalmers Report did, however, recommend that medical practitioners operating IVF programs should be regulated by a scheme of Ministerial licensing. The report is still under consideration.

26. In South Australia a Select Committee of the Legislative Council reported (the Connor Report) in April 1987. The Connor Report recommendations have been substantially incorporated by the introduction of the Reproductive Technology Bill into the South Australian Parliament.

27. In Western Australia the Government has under consideration a report in this area (the Meadow Report, September 1986). This recommends that experimental research on spare embryos produced in an IVF program should be permissible if approved by a State licensing authority, which would license all premises and persons engaged in artificial conception procedures.

28. In New South Wales the Law Reform Commission of that State is presently working on an artificial conception reference. In July 1987, it released a detailed Discussion Paper which tentatively favoured properly conducted research, subject to conditions, on any embryo produced in an IVF program in licensed institutions for specific purposes including the alleviating of infertility, disease, abnormality of birth and relief of human suffering. In coming to this tentative conclusion, the Law Reform Commission did not accept the arguments for limiting embryo experimentation to either therapeutic experimentation, as recommended by the Senate Committee, or to experimentation on spare embryos produced in an IVF program as recommended by several of the State reports. The Law Reform Commission also tentatively concluded in its Discussion Paper that effective regulation of IVF may be accomplished without blanket licensing requirements extending to every aspect of its practice.
29. An IVF program has not been established in the Northern Territory and its Government has not, in these circumstances, called for a report on these issues.

30. It is clear to the Government from the findings of the various State Commissions and Enquiries and the State governments' responses to them that no consensus of expert or political opinion on these difficult issues has been reached in Australia at this time.

31. The Victorian experience has highlighted the difficulties in developing legislation in this area. Problems have arisen in determining whether research falls within the prohibitive provisions which are contained in the Victorian legislation. It is clear that there is a grey area dependent largely on medical opinion.
32. The explicit constitutional power over clinical medicine and biomedical research rests with the States.

33. It may be that the Commonwealth's implied powers under s122 (The Territories Power), s51 (xx) (The Corporations Power) and s51 (xviii) (The Patents Power) provide a limited base for legislation in the field of human embryo experimentation but would not be sufficient to support comprehensive national legislation. Senator Harradine's prohibitive approach to human embryo experimentation is based upon such a use of a number of the Commonwealth's powers.

34. The Senate Committee recognises the Commonwealth's legislative limitation and any comprehensive legislative approach could only be achieved by co-operation between the Federal and State Legislatures and Governments. Such co-operation has not been forthcoming from the States, nor at this time is there any consensus among the States and Territories regarding the appropriate level of IVF practice and research.

35. In these circumstances the Government does not propose to implement the Senate Committee's recommendation for legislation establishing a co-operative accreditation and licensing system incorporating the prohibition of destructive non-therapeutic experimentation. The matter will be kept under review and the Government will further consider it in the light of experience and any advice received from the National Bioethics Consultative Committee which the Government proposes to establish and to which I now turn.

36. There is significant Commonwealth and State consensus regarding the desirability of a national body on reproductive technology. The Government has, through the Australian Health Ministers' Conference and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, achieved agreement with the States to establish a National Bioethics Consultative Committee having a broad charter including, but also going beyond, reproductive technology.

37. The co-operation of the States and Territories with such a body is vital in order to achieve a national uniform approach to bioethical issues. A purely Commonwealth body would only be of limited value.
38. We are therefore proceeding, in co-operation with all States and Territories, to establish this national body.

39. This national body will provide a forum for ideas and issues to be publicly debated and analysed outside of the political arena. It will also mark the first national interdisciplinary group to provide guidance to policy makers on some of the most difficult, complex, ethical and moral problems of our time.
40. The Government sees the national body as having a consultative role and not being involved directly in the regulation of research or the licensing of institutions.

41. Clearly such a body should have a broadly based membership including people from the general community and people with expertise in philosophy, ethics, women's health, biomedical research, law, the practice of medicine, and health care provision. The existing national and State bodies currently involved in bioethics such as the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Medical Research Ethics Committee and the Standing Review and Advisory Committee on Infertility would be consulted on all relevant issues.
42. These appointments will be made by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health following wide consultation with State Ministers and Attorneys-General.
43. In bringing forward advice on issues referred to it, the national body will consult widely with the public to be able to truly represent community opinion.

44. It is felt that the establishment of the National Bioethics Consultative Committee will provide the next essential step towards developing a uniform approach to bioethical issues arising out of areas such as reproductive technology.

45. Finally, the Government would like to take this opportunity to thank both the members of the Senate Committee and the Family Law Council for their valuable work in this most difficult and controversial area.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: We are appalled that the Government has taken so long to respond to both of these reports. I say that because, firstly, both these reports-as the Special Minister of State acknowledges in the statement she has tabled-deal with some very fundamental issues that affect many Australians. Secondly, a significant amount of effort was put in by the Senate Committee on these very sensitive matters.
