In our view a response at this late hour is disrespectful to the effort of those senators. Their work deserves a fuller debate than will be possible this afternoon.

It is also a disgrace that this matter has been brought on in the dying hours of this session because only the Senate is sitting. Given this Government's attitude to the Senate, it is somewhat surprising that such an important matter is being raised here and the House of Representatives will not have the opportunity to discuss the Government's response to these two reports in the parliamentary forum until February next year. The Minister and the Government may think it is acceptable that the response was tabled here only. But I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that, apart from the fact that this report deals with fundamental issues that ought to be addressed by Parliament as a whole, it touches specifically on two portfolios-that of the Attorney-General and that of Community Services and Health. I remind the Minister that the relevant Ministers and shadow Ministers are in the other place. Therefore, that is an additional reason why it is so appalling that this response-or what is alleged to be a response-to some very detailed work by senators and others is brought on in the dying hours of this Parliament.

In this alleged response the Government rejects the Senate Select Committee's recommendation that the Federal Parliament, by legislation, make it unlawful to carry out destructive non-therapeutic experimentation on human embryos. It does so with three reasons in mind. Firstly, the primary legislative responsibility is with the States. Secondly, it draws attention to the fact that the States have not ignored that responsibility; some of them have legislation and some of them have sought reports on this area, and indicate, therefore, that they will be acting in the future. Thirdly, there is insufficient constitutional power for the Commonwealth to act in this area. In this statement the Minister points out that any legislation in this area produces difficult grey areas. She refers in particular to legislation in Victoria. I have no doubt that what she said in that respect is true. But it is not really an adequate reason for not proceeding, because a variety of pieces of legislation create grey areas. We manage to live with them in other areas and I do not see that it is a substantive reason in itself.

I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that in the report she details what happens in the States and leaves out the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I am aware of the fact that the ACT does not have an in vitro fertilisation research program. Nonetheless, the ACT should be included, almost as a courtesy to its people. There is no reason why they should be left out when the Northern Territory is mentioned. In the paper the Minister says that the Government has consulted with the States, but unless my memory fails me-and Senator Harradine may have some more to say about this-I recall responses by the Minister to Senator Harradine quite recently indicating that there had not been formal consultations with my State and, accordingly, that makes the statement that the States have been consulted look a bit thin and, at the very least, is indicative of a last minute job.

The Minister says that the Government will establish a National Bioethics Consultative Committee, which will look at, but will not be restricted to, human reproductive technology. The Minister told us that in July. The only new thing she has told us today-I concede that she has announced that the National Bioethics Consultative Committee will not limit itself to human reproductive technology, which, as I understand it, was not said in July-is who will make the appointments to the Committee, indicating the range of the membership of that Committee. But that is all she has told us. The Minister could have announced in one sentence that the Government had decided as a further response that not only was it establishing a National Bioethics Committee but it would consider other than human reproductive technology. The Minister could have detailed who would make appointments and indicated the range of membership. In that respect, this response offers nothing more. We are not told who can refer to that Committee, how it will report, whether the reports will be tabled in Parliament or how long the appointments will be for. I could go on for some time about the administrative options, once one has decided to have a national bioethics committee, which are not addressed in this report. It is a pathetic response to a quite detailed suggestion put forward by the Senate Select Committee.

The Minister recently went overseas at taxpayers' expense. Her agenda in the United States of America included several meetings to discuss issues pertaining to the establishment of a national bioethics committee. Six months have passed since the Minister first announced that we were to have a national bioethics committee. The Minister went on an overseas trip and, as I understand, took a staff member with her, and still we have not really advanced. We have just been told a few little extra bits and pieces about this committee, despite the fact that, at taxpayers' expense, the Minister has had an overseas trip, allegedly to discuss these matters.

It is a very poor final effort from the Minister to produce this statement to the chamber in the dying hours of this Parliament. I am sure that the senators who were members of that Senate Select Committee and others who have a particular interest in this area will detail for this chamber the points that are not addressed in this statement. If one were simply to talk to this statement, one might not have a lot to say; but if one links it back to the report, one will see how very thin on the ground this response is. I simply repeat that it is a very poor effort from the Minister in the dying hours of this Parliament. It is an insult to the people--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament has two years to run.

—Of this session. It is a poor effort and it is an insult to the senators who put in so much work on the Senate Selection Committee. The coalition says that, if the Government were serious about this, the response would have been more detailed and the Government would have outlined why it was not accepting some of the recommendations, rather than simply saying that it was not. The Government would have outlined why it is more appropriate to go the way it has chosen rather than to do what the Senate Select Committee and the Family Law Council suggested. This statement is very thin on the ground and an unsatisfactory response from the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This long delayed response by Senator Ryan represents an attack on the principles of parliamentary democracy and responsible government and ignores the well reasoned and soundly based recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, especially its chief recommendation that human embryos be protected by law from destructive experimentation which would frustrate their development.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement is a response to two reports, that is, the report of the Family Law Council-for shorthand purposes I will describe it as the Asche report-and the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985, shorthanded the Tate report. Senator Tate chaired the latter Committee and Justice Asche chaired the former. The Asche report was submitted to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in August 1985. The Tate report was tabled in this Parliament in October 1986. Both reports urged action to prevent experimentation on human embryos. The Asche report dealt with areas which were not within the terms of reference of the Tate Committee. Why does Senator Ryan, who is the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), bring down a Government response to the Family Law Council report which was submitted to the Attorney-General?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they were done together.

—But why did Senator Ryan bring down a response to the report of the Tate Committee which said that the Attorney-General should have the running on this matter? An explanation should be given by Senator Ryan on the last day of her existence as a member of parliament. I express my support for the comment that was made that this is an attack on the principles of parliamentary democracy and responsible government. In this report the Government acknowledges that the issue of human embryo experimentation is fundamental, going to the very nature of life itself and to the value of society. It is a major question of public policy which should not be left to non-elected cliques to determine but, in a democracy, should be determined by the elected representatives of the people who are answerable to the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Either it is a major question of public policy or it is not. Yet the Minister's response, to pass the issue over to a non-elected National Bioethics Consultative Committee, is an abdication of the responsibility of an elected government to decide its view on one of the most vital of all public policy issues facing this nation and the world and to bring legislation to the Parliament in respect of that matter. This issue is long overdue for determination by the elected representatives of the people. After all, the Asche Committee inquired over quite a long period. It has had its report in since 1985. The Tate Committee has had its report in since October 1986. Here we have a document which does not even address the well-reasoned recommendations of the Tate Committee or the Asche Committee. All it says is, `We will cop out of this and we will hand it over for, perhaps, another 10 years to a non-elected bio-ethics consultative council'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which has no power.

—Of course not. That is the situation we have to address. The Minister's response is inept. It does not address the major questions that have been raised and dealt with by the Senate Committee. Where, in this document of the Minister, does she deal with the issues which were dealt with quite adequately in the Senate Committee report? Chapter 1, for example, sets out the issues. Chapter 2 sets out the meaning of human embryo experimentation. Where, in this document tabled by the Minister, does she address the difference between therapeutic and non-therapeutic destructive experimentation on human embryos? She does not deal with that at all. She does not make that distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a difficult question. Obviously, it was too difficult for her. But it was not too difficult for members of the Tate Committee, after considering all of the evidence from experts and others, to come up with certain recommendations based on the well known, internationally accepted differences between non-therapeutic destructive experimentation and experimentation which was for the benefit of the human subject. She does not even deal with that in the document; there is no mention of it.

The document refers to the ethical issues, for example, between so-called spare embryos and so-called specially created embryos. There is a mention of it in regard to the Senate Committee, but the Minister does not address that issue; nor does she address the basis upon which the Tate Committee founded its recommendations. There was a firm basis of understanding of international protocols relating to experimentation on human subjects which arose out of the problems in nazi Germany concentration camps and which are very vital for the future of this nation and, indeed, the world. It was also based on our concepts of guardianship in domestic law. That issue is not even addressed. I could go on, but I will not do so, because a number of senators wish to speak in this debate.

The Tate Committee, in the spirit of Australian parliamentary committees of inquiry-whose members had a wide variety and diversity of views and background-attempted to reach common ground on the resultant report, including the description of the human embryo, couched in minimum, measured and restrained terms, based on the evidence before it. I am quite disappointed that the Minister has chosen not to address those well reasoned arguments. Her response is, in fact, a temporary victory for the deliberate, concerted and organised attempts by some science technologists with a vested interest in human embryo experimentation, supported by the Medical Research Ethics Committee (MREC) to prevent this issue from coming to Parliament, where it belongs. Indeed, much of this campaign has been funded from the medical research endowment fund. In fact, $450,000 of that fund has gone to the Monash Bioethics Centre.

The argument to prevent the matter being properly considered by Parliament is based on this project which is funded by the taxpayer. I have asked questions about that and I am expecting a response, as are a large number of medical doctors and scientists who have had their medical research projects approved but who have been told that there is no money in the fund. The requests for funding for many of those beneficial research projects on cancer and the like have totalled only $6,000. Yet this group has been able to get, with the support of the National Health and Medical Research Council, $450,000. Over the last three months the Minister, sad to say, has been part and parcel of that campaign. It is all very well for her to abdicate her responsibility as a sort of departing gesture in the dying hours of the sitting of this Parliament, but this issue will not go away. Those who remain will have to face the issue and decide it.

Parliamentarians who take seriously their responsibility to represent the people will take exception to the calculated insults that are contained in this paper. There are a number of them. It is clear that the Government intends to use the National Bioethics Consultative Committee as an excuse for delaying decisions on human embryo experimentation and also as an excuse to pass over to the Committee other hard decisions. This document simply says that. Let me tell honourable senators what the next decision is that the Government will pass over to this body-euthanasia. That is the question that Professor Peter Singer, the utilitarian philosopher who has received this money, wants to go to such a committee. It was his idea in the first place, published in 1984, in the Reproduction Revolution, that a national bioethics commission be established. He stated:

Stimulating public debate would be part of the brief of such a Commission. The role of this debate would be to ensure that all the information and arguments came out into the open: the Commission would not be aiming at accommodating all points of view in its final recommendations, since, as we have seen, some views are mutually contradictory. On the contrary, sometimes the Commission might have to challenge widely held but ill-founded moral beliefs. It cannot do this if consensus is its main aim.

It is a strange situation where the Government says, `There can be no consensus, therefore set up this commission'. And here it is. What is being said here is that this Commission is going to be used as a propaganda tool to prevent these matters from coming to the Parliament where they belong. Others may have different views from mine on this matter but it is a question of major public policy and it ought to be determined here, and it is high time that it was.

Some interesting points should be raised very quickly here. I refer to the people the Government is looking at putting on this Committee. It is very noticeable that Professor Max Charlesworth, in an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-Michael Kirby was there also-on 27 October, talking about a bioethics commission, had some rather interesting observations to make about the legislature. I thought they were rather quaint ideas from an academic. When talking about whether lesbian couples should be allowed to have children through in vitro fertilisation on taxpayers' funds, he said:

The question hasn't come up in the past, however, whether lesbian couples should be allowed to have children through in vitro fertilisation means, et cetera. Most people, I think, up until the present time have said, `No, we don't think that would be a legitimate use of public funds to allow that'. But these are precisely the sorts of questions that do need to be discussed, I think, in open forum.
I do not know whether the Minister is thinking of appointing Professor Charlesworth as the chairman of this committee but listen to this:
No one has got the right answer and in a sense there's no right answer because they're extraordinarily difficult questions.
They're all in the grey area. They can't be settled by legislation but we do need public discussion about them so that we've got some kind of general consensus about them.

That issue of general consensus was also addressed by Mr Russell Scott. His draft paper was mentioned by the Minister in her paper. I refer very briefly to page 8. There is a rather large paragraph on the New South Wales Law Reform Commission recommendation. Mr Russell Scott is not the chairman of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission; he was in charge of this particular reference. But it is interesting to note what Mr Russell Scott feels about this matter. He has indicated that there should not be legislation on the question of human embryo experimentation. His committee recommended to the New South Wales Government that it not legislate against experiments on human embryos to the time of implantation. However, he admitted that his recommendation as to time limit was not based on the inherent status of the human embryo but simply reflects `a judgment of community feeling'. His report went on to say:
. . . it may be that in the future the time limit would be extended, for example from the time of implantation to the stage before development of sentience.
In other words, that could be up to eight weeks. It continued:
Such extension would be related to community opinion and acceptance at the time.

In other words, he is saying that it would be a case of what the market will bear. This is totally against what I would expect Australian Labor Party policy to be. It is a laissez-faire policy dictated by the science technologists with a vested interest in human embryo experimentation.

I make one other point on commercialisation. The Asche Committee referred specifically to the problem of commercialisation in this area. Of course, the Tate Committee had that in mind when it made its recommendations. There is nothing in this document by the Minister which deals with that question. I know that others wish to speak, so I will finish by giving two very quick quotes from this document. At page 6, paragraph 20, there is this bland assertion:
The States are not inclined to support a uniform prohibitive approach . . .
Yet at page 10 paragraph 37 states:
The co-operation of the States and Territories with such a body-
that is, the proposed national body-
is vital in order to achieve a national uniform approach to bioethical issues.
What is the Minister telling us? At page 20 the document states that the States are not inclined to support a uniform prohibitive approach, then at page 10, in paragraph 37, it states:
The co-operation of the States and Territories with such a body is vital in order to achieve a national uniform approach to bioethical issues.

What she is saying there is that there will be a uniform approach, but only on her conditions, that is, that human embryo experimentation continues. She knows as well as I do that her unit in the health department tried to interfere with the legislative process in South Australia. The South Australian Government put forward a Bill to establish a reproductive technology council which would say yea or nay to experimentation on human embryos. I am glad to say that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in the Legislative Council, having read and understood the Tate Committee report, introduced an amendment, which was successful, which in fact prohibits any experiment detrimental to a human embryo. The next day the Minister of Health there welcomed that total Bill, saying that it provided a proper balance.

In this document the Minister says that the States do not want a uniform prohibitive approach. South Australia will get one, and Victoria has one to a certain extent because of the infertility medical procedures legislation. The Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, stated publicly only last week that he was opposed to human embryo experimentation. That leaves Barrie Unsworth, Brian Burke and Robin Gray. I do not know what Robin Gray's view on this matter is, but I would be very interested to find out. I very much doubt whether Barrie Unsworth would accept proposals of the Scott type, and I very much doubt whether Brian Burke would want to have human embryo experimentation and leave it up to the science technologists with a vested interest. Senator Vanstone said in relation to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) that this response is an abdication by the Minister in respect of her or the Government's responsibilities so far as the ACT is concerned.

This is a question that needs to be determined sooner rather than later. Putting the matter off by referring it to a bioethics committee will make the determination come much later; and it will be too late, because today the smallest member of our human family is under threat. Today there are science technologists who want to experiment on human embryos just as freely as if they were rhesus monkeys or laboratory rats. The quest for knowledge is not the only driving force behind this experimentation. Today human embryos are at the point of being grown, because of commercialisation, as a cash crop. They are on the point of finally being sold to the highest bidder, through IVF Australia and its associated company in the United States of America-all in the name of science, progress, humanity and profit. Finally, I repeat one simple statement though it is not my own. I read this somewhere in a technical journal and I cannot remember who wrote it: `Ten years ago proposals now being made for human embryo experimentation were the basis of science fiction horror. Today they require scholarly demolition; tomorrow our objections may appear to be quaint'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In September 1986 the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 brought forward a most important report on human embryo experimentation. Now, 15 months later, in the last hours of this session of Parliament, the Government has decided to bring in its response. I am sure not only I but all senators on the Committee-including Senator Tate, who was Chairman and who unfortunately is not present for this debate-will be most disappointed that the Government has not seen fit to accept the recommendations of that Committee and has decided that there is no need for the introduction of legislation on this most important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Harradine pointed out in his motion on Wednesday, the Government has totally misunderstood the Committee's report. Indeed, the Attorney-General's Department annual report concluded that the key recommendation in our report was the establishment of a national body to regulate and licence in those areas of in vitro fertilisation (IVF) research. While this was one of our most important recommendations, our key recommendation was stipulated as the principle protecting the embryo from destructive, non-therapeutic experimentation. I hope that the Senate will take this into consideration.

No marker event prior to which one should consider that any type of experimentation can take place was found by the Committee. No evidence whatsoever was brought to us to indicate that there was a marker event significant enough to suggest that prior to a certain stage experimentation of any description should be allowed and after that stage it should not be allowed. Whenever people mentioned the time of implantation we questioned them thoroughly on what that time was. We had varying responses. Dr Jansen, who is the director of the IVF clinic in Sydney, said that implantation can start on the seventh day. He is also a member of the Medical Research Ethics Committee. The other members of that Committee say that it could be 10 to 14 days. For those people who thought that it was from the moment of implantation, I stress that it was not from implantation but from the date that implantation normally takes place. We questioned everyone very closely about this stage. We asked why they picked a particular date. They just said, `That seems a pretty good time'. There is no evidence at all that life does not begin from the moment of fertilisation. It is obvious, if one witnesses it, that the cell starts dividing immediately. And of course it is human life. Nobody suggested that it was anything else. There is no evidence that it was any other type of life. Of course, no one suggested, no matter how radical, that that was not when life began.

We could not come up with any marker event because no scientific evidence was given to us in that respect. As I have said, we questioned everyone very closely on that particular issue because we thought that it was most important. As a result, we brought down what we believed were two types of experimentation. One was therapeutic, which was, in general terms, for the good of the embryo. We said that this could be a fairly blurred area. We said that as long as the scientist believed that what he was doing was or would be for the ultimate good of the embryo, then that would be therapeutic. The second type of experimentation was destructive non-therapeutic, the deliberate destruction of the embryo. It could not be classed in any way as being for the good of the embryo. As has already been said, this was our key recommendation: that there should be no destructive non-therapeutic experimentation at any stage once the egg was fertilised, but that it would be right for therapeutic experimentation to go ahead. A number of our research scientists in this field were happy with that recommendation. We believe that at the moment the present system of voluntary regulation of IVF research is inadequate.

The National Health and Medical Research Council has voluntary guidelines. I do not want honourable senators to think for one moment that it does not set guidelines, albeit they are voluntary. However, it became very clear to us that these voluntary guidelines were not substantial enough or supported sufficiently. We became very aware that there was in the States and the various ethics committees considerable scope for determining their own implantation date and the sorts of experimentations that would be undertaken. So every State does not have to abide by uniform guidelines. Therefore, we found that the situation was totally inadequate. We believed that a licensed national body should put out guidelines that were acceptable to the community. The Government in its response has ignored that recommendation completely.

The Government has gone through what is happening in the States and said, `You see, the States don't agree, so we can't do anything about it'. Let me go through the States. The Waller Committee in Victoria reported in 1983 and 1984 that the research should be confined by an Act to institutions licensed by a standing review and advisory committee. It is very important to note that the Waller Committee in Victoria said that there should be licensed institutions. In 1984 the Victorian Government passed an Act to prohibit research procedures which would result in damage to the embryo, except where it had been approved by a standing review and advisory committee. But it is important to note that Victoria also went for licensed institutions.

In Queensland the Demack Committee also came out and said that IVF and embryo transfers should be performed only at centres licensed by the Director-General of Health for that State. Queensland has not yet picked up the recommendations of the Demack committee, but it is looking at them. In Tasmania the Chalmers committee decided that national guidelines should be set down. The report recommended that medical practitioners operating IVF programs should be regulated by a scheme of ministerial licensing. The Western Australian committee says exactly the same thing-that an IVF program should be permissible if approved by a State licensing authority.
Like Victoria, South Australia has already passed legislation. That legislation was passed only on the twenty-sixth of last month. A news report stated:
Destructive experimentation on human embryos . . . will be banned in SA under legislation which passed through the Legislative Council yesterday.
It went on to say:
Non-invasive or non-destructive research will be allowed . . .

Obviously South Australia has picked up the report and recommendations of our Committee. So far, as I have just said, all of the reports that are coming through have suggested that there should be a licensing body.

The Law Reform Commission in New South Wales, which is at the moment working on a reference, has already come out tentatively favouring properly conducted research, subject to conditions on any embryo produced in the IVF program in licensed institutions. Every State has come out in favour of the need for a licence or regulation. Yet, the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) in her report sums up what is happening in the various States by saying:

It is clear to the Government from the findings of the various State Commissions and Enquiries and the State Governments' responses to them that no consensus of expert or political opinion on these difficult issues has been reached in Australia at this time.

That is a lot of rot. Every one of them has suggested that we license the institutions. For the Minister to brush this off and say that there has been no consensus of expert opinion is just not true. It concerns me considerably that that has been said. The Government is saying that there is no co-operation between the States and, therefore, the Government cannot do anything about national guidelines and national licensing. I have found this Government to be a very centralist government. In the past, it has found it very easy to introduce legislation stopping the damming of the Franklin River, for example. While I would not suggest for one moment that it should have such a centralist power-and I sincerely hope it never will have-I do not believe that it has conferred with the States. Senator Vanstone said today that the Government had not officially conferred with South Australia.

The point is that this Government hands out the money. It gives money for research to the National Health and Medical Research Council. All that council has to do is say that only those research units that are licensed can be funded. It is a very simple thing for the Government, should it want, to be able to make sure that such important research and experimentation be undertaken in a proper, regulated and licensed fashion. It was a unanimous decision of our Committee. As has been stressed, two senators voiced a minority view but they, too, said that there should be licensed institutions to do this research. Should there be a need for licensing? Before I was a member of this Committee, I did not quite see the need as much as I do now. Some of the evidence we took, would literally make one's hair stand on end.

Let us consider one of the papers by Professor Carl Wood. In the name of science he introduced a human embryo into the uterus of a sheep. He says in his paper that it was probably just as well that the experiment did not come off because he would have had a hard time explaining it to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gametes.

—I am sorry, not a fertilised cell-the egg and the sperm were introduced. He also thought that injecting female hormones into a male embryo may reduce the aggressive traits of males without altering the reproductive capacity of that embryo. These sorts of things are of great concern to people outside. During one of the hearings we had been discussing embryos being grown for spare parts. That sounds a bit emotive but embryos, at certain stages, could be used for tissues. Over a cup of tea, I was asked, `Just think: if you had a three-year-old daughter who was going blind, would you deliberately become pregnant and grow that foetus in your uterus until it was old enough for its retinas to be used to save your daughter's sight?'. That really made me feel sick. My response was that no woman should ever be asked to make that decision. I do not believe that anyone in this chamber would think that women should ever be asked to make that decision. But that is the scientific thinking in this area, and let us not hide our heads and say that is emotive, because that was put to me by a person who is very eminent in this field. I was told that I should think about it. If we in this chamber hide our heads to that sort of questioning, I think that this Parliament has a lot to answer for.

SPEECH.PARA: We had evidence from Professor Singer, who has just been given a grant from the National Health and Medical Research Council of $190,676 over a period of three years. Let me just read a little of his evidence, because I think it is very important that we should know what the scientists who are using taxpayers' money are thinking. This Government is saying that these scientists should not be restricted by legislation because they are all very responsible and are all doing the right thing, and there is no need even to regulate or license the institutions to which they belong. It is very important that we know how these people are thinking. This is what Professor Singer said:
Once an embryo may be capable of feeling pain, I believe that we need very strict controls over the experimentation which can be done with it.
He went on:

The capacity to feel pain is enough to entitle a being to moral consideration. There are, however, different forms moral consideration can take. A right not to have pain inflicted upon one unnecessarily is not the same as a right to life. Finally, then, when does the developing person acquire a right to life? I would argue, following Michael Tooley, who has discussed this matter very thoroughly in his recent book Abortion and Infanticide that there must be something more: a sense of self, an awareness of the continuity of one's existence over time, a knowledge that one has a past and may have a future and the capacity to have desires about that future.
He says that the only time that one should have a right to life is when one is aware of one's future, aware of being and aware of desires over a future. He went on:

I think we can be confident that no embryo or foetus has these capacities. It is of course true that in this respect too birth does not make a morally crucial dividing line, for the newborn infant equally lacks this kind of self-awareness. But this raises another topic, which I cannot go into now.
He goes into it in another book. This man, this scientist, believes that newborn babies, until they have a form of sense, a desire of the future, have no right to life.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish.

—It is absolute rubbish. However, the National Health and Medical Research Council has funded this man to the tune of $63,558 for three consecutive years-a total of $190,676. That was the evidence he gave. I agree with Senator Puplick that that is absolute rubbish. We must have legislation that provides national guidelines. We must have guidelines that ensure that the National Health and Medical Research Council can go only so far. The legislation must ensure that the Council cannot grow foetuses to be used for spare parts; and that it cannot say that a small baby who desires for the future has no right to life. That is not the sort of scientist that we, as taxpayers, are willing to fund.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know why the Government has taken this attitude. I do not know why the Government has chosen to have a national body to decide just which matters should be discussed-which matters should be brought up for discussion and general advice. I do not know why this Government has chosen to shut its eyes. I hope and pray-I am very sincere in this-that there will not be some dreadful tragedy before the Government comes to its senses and before the population out there realises what can happen. I can almost understand the situation. I guess if I were a scientist and very involved in a particular issue I might be tempted to ask, `I wonder what would happen if I did this and this?'. It would be very easy to get carried away with the scientific life and the scientific approach. I guess if one were dealing with embryos 12 hours a day it could be very easy to get carried away.

It is up to the people of Australia to say how far these scientists should go and where the guidelines should rest. I really believe that unless we do that we in this Parliament will be very sorry. In the past we have warned the Government on many issues. Again I warn the Government that the National Health and Medical Research Council has come out very clearly and said that it does not want legislation, that it does not see the need for legislation and that it believes that it can control the situation. However, when that august body grants money to people such as Professor Singer, who gave evidence to our Committee in the fashion he did, this Council, in whom we have put our faith to be able to guide our research in this very important area, cannot understand that he has these thoughts. That Council should have listened to the evidence that he gave us. Maybe the Council is unaware that Professor Singer has given this evidence. I appeal to the Government, for heaven's sake, to take note and to make sure that nothing dreadful happens before it brings in legislation. Indeed, if something does happen, the Government will be held responsible by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take a great deal of time. I believe we have already heard a little filibustering on this matter, and I think other people, particularly members of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation, have the right to speak in this debate, and I know that time is short. I therefore do not want to take the time of the Senate to answer all of the points made by Senator Harradine and Senator Walters, much as I would like to because I believe some of them were fairly outrageous-for example, Senator Walters's discussion of the marker event. I consider that she gave a totally inaccurate description of the evidence that we heard before the inquiry. I do not want to answer the various relatively detailed points, let alone go into the broader philosophical issues which both of those speakers tried to address, and which obviously cannot be adequately addressed, without taking a great deal more time than is available. Some people, myself included, have the view that we live in a pluralist society.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone seemed to consider it a disgrace that this report was brought forward today, in the dying hours of this session. Would she have preferred that it be left over to the next session and so deny community discussion in the meantime, let alone progress on the actual setting up of the national body? I find that attitude hard to accept, particularly in view of the lengthy, and at times extremely repetitive, debates that we have had this week simply because the proceedings have been broadcast every day since the House of Representatives has been in recess. I speak as a member of that Committee and as one of the two women authors of the dissenting report. I would like to refer to a few points that Senator Harradine made. I may be misquoting the term he used but he referred to this report as being a `cop-out'. I think that is what he meant.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response.

—I am sorry, he says that the response was a cop-out. Most of the matters addressed in the recommendations of the majority report and, indeed, the minority report are in the hands of the States. I was surprised to hear Senator Walters apparently looking for a more centralist point of view. That is not the usual stance she takes, particularly in matters which concern her State of Tasmania. Senator Harradine also referred to this as being a major public policy issue. I would very seriously challenge the assertion that this is a major public policy issue in the eyes of the vast majority of the population. I think a reading of the list of people and groups who appeared before the Committee would show that it is not a major public policy issue in the eyes of the vast majority of the population. He also referred to a wide diversity of views on the part of members of the Committee. I simply make the point, which can be verified by an examination of the membership of that committee, that it is not really representative of a range of community attitudes, particularly, I believe, or a range of religious and social attitudes, but I do not intend to go into detail on that either.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to the very positive recommendation of the report to set up a National Bioethics Consultative Committee, which will have a much wider scope of operation than just human embryo experimentation which, of course, was the Committee's term of reference. One of the fears expressed by a number of witnesses, particularly by some of the feminist groups that appeared before us, was that this was the thin end of the wedge; in other words, if some experimentation in this area is allowed it will lead to all kinds of things such as cloning and the sorts of fanciful things we read about in science fiction. I do not think the thin end of the wedge argument can ever be considered a logical one. But that sort of argument is adequately answered by the setting up of this body which will cover all bioethical issues-not just the narrow ones which were considered by our Committee-whether those issues are in research or in the practical applications of that research. A lot of things are being experimented with in medicine today which will not only prolong life but also greatly increase the quality of life on earth.

I welcome the setting up of this body and I would like to say that its setting up does not imply criticism of the present Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, to which I pay tribute. I think the members of that Committee have done an extremely good job with very limited resources and very limited time available, as they are all part time members and cover the whole of Australia. I pay tribute to that very responsible and widely-based Committee that represents a range of community views including the views of Dr McCaughey, the present Governor of Victoria, who retains an interest in that Committee.

I was shocked by Senator Walters's suggestion of thought control when she was talking about Professor Peter Singer. She said that she did not think the National Health and Medical Research Council would have given a grant to Dr Singer if it had understood what he was thinking. It is extraordinary that the thoughts of somebody in one area could be taken into account in denying that person the right to a research grant in some totally different field.

I welcome particularly paragraphs 42 and 43 of the statement by the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) referring to the composition of the National Bioethics Consultative Committee. I will not take time to read its composition because I know that other people wish to speak in the short time available. But I point out that it does not actually refer to the representation of women on the Committee. I believe, unlike some on the other side of the Senate who spoke last night, that these days we do not have to spell that out. I trust that this Government will ensure, and I hope that future governments will ensure, that wide representation in the community means people of both gender as well as people with expertise or particular community beliefs or thoughts. I assume that that Committee will reflect the interests of women and the interests of consumers and potential consumers when considering the benefits of research in the bioethics area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Zakharov for speaking only briefly to enable me to make some comments on the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985. As a member of that Committee and as a signatory of the majority report I am disappointed with the Government's response to the major recommendation of that majority report, which was to seek a co-operative legislative arrangement so that institutions could be accredited for the purposes of research in this area and proposals for the consideration of those licences would conform with Commonwealth legislation. The majority report proposed that that Commonwealth legislation would have a broad declaration of principle concerning this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I say I am disappointed because I think this is one of the major difficulties that we are facing in this legislature with regard to committee reports. Essentially, detailed investigatory activities are being undertaken by members of parliament as representatives of the people. The whole exercise is then being counter-guessed by bureaucrats who are accountable to no one. That may be fun and games for everybody concerned but, at the end of the day, it is absolutely counter-productive to the operation of reasonable committee stages in this chamber. I think at some stage we will really have to come to grips with this major problem because time and again the bureaucrats' responses really start a long way back from where a particular committee has actually ended. Often, as is the case here, they have started even further back than where the committee started. Although I did not agree with Senator Zakharov's findings, I think that if we compared this report with her minority report, this one shows a lamentable understanding of the issues. Even Senator Zakharov had a grasp of them at the end of her report. It shows a very shallow understanding of the major points that were raised in this area.

I am concerned about this essential conundrum that faces us. The Committee members-and I was one-came to this particular investigation with a view contrary to the majority report that I eventually signed. I am happy enough to say that now; I had quite a different view. But in listening to representatives of women's, scientific and religious groups and the various ethics boards that came before us, we were led inexorably to the conclusions which were in the majority report. That was my understanding. I am quite happy to accept that it may be faulty. These types of deliberations are fraught with an enormous number of problems. But at least I was exposed to all those community influences. At least I, as a representative of the people, tried to wrestle with the problem and come to some conclusion which I felt was generally one which the community would accept. The bureaucrats had no such input-they give advice off the tops of their heads in a cloistered environment here in Canberra. I strongly object to this type of exercise being imposed on us, particularly when we have this type of shallow exercise. It is shallow and it shows no understanding of the enormously complex range of issues with which one has to grapple in this area, and they are complex.

I respect people who come down on both sides of this particular issue. I do not think it is cut and dried; that is not the case at all. It is a very difficult matter. Some of the most difficult times that we had in this Committee were when we sat and listened to men and women who wanted to have children but were not able to do so. As members of parliament we at least have something that the bureaucrats do not have. We have a grounding in listening and understanding and trying to empathise with the general views which are held by people in the community. I think that is what the Committee tried to bring to its final report.

I am not saying that because of that we were right. I am saying that because of the influences that we were exposed to and because of the attempt to grapple with those particular types of problems in a constructive and realistic way, we came up with a final conclusion which was reasonably acceptable to the majority of the community. It did not seek to cut off in-vitro fertilisation funding or research, as some people have suggested. It did not seek to do any of those things. It sought to put it into a regulatory environment that took account of the diversity of views which exist within our community. It did not go as far as Senator Harradine, who initiated the proposal, would have wished. It sought a stance which was hopefully as representative as it could be of those items. I believe that it is representative.

I do not think that the Government's response sought to grapple with any of those complex views that were put to us or tried to enunciate precisely why the Government was unwilling to respond by going down the track recommended by the Committee. It did not attempt to come to grips with that at all in this very shallow document. I think that essentially that is a pity. I hope that over time all senators may give some consideration to the way in which report after report which comes into this place-reports which, when compared to similar items existing either within Australia or elsewhere, are invariably held to be of the highest standing-is then treated in such a cavalier and off-handed fashion by the bureaucrats who write the responses. This majority report of the Committee was received in the international circles as a major contribution to thought in this area. When combined, the majority and minority reports clearly show the two sides of the argument. I consider it an insult to both the majority and minority members on that Committee to have this type of Government response before us. I hope that the Government will reconsider its position and at least read in detail not only the report but also the exhaustive transcripts of evidence taken. Perhaps the bureaucrats who are advising the Minister will educate themselves a little to be able to write a reasonable response to a very detailed and worthwhile report.

Finally may I say a word on the record-not nearly as many as I would like to-about my friend and colleague Susan Ryan, whose last day in the Senate this is. I simply want to say that Susan has been an outstandingly intelligent and sensitive parliamentarian and Minister in her 12 years in this place. She has been an ornament to the women's movement, the Australian Capital Territory, the Australian Labor Party and the Hawke Government. I know she will become an equally glittering ornament to the Australian publishing industry, and I wish her every success in that new career.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of Government senators, I wish to make some remarks about the contribution of my colleague Senator Ryan, who will leave the chamber before we reconvene next year. Listening to some of the churlish interjections of the Opposition, I was reminded of that great story about somebody buried in a British graveyard. On the tombstone the words appeared, `Here lies so and so, an honest man and a lawyer'. Somebody looking at the grave remarked, `There are two people buried in this grave'. A lot of the interjections from the other side of the House have that sort of flavour about them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan was elected to the Senate for the Australian Capital Territory in 1975. That was the year after a very good vintage year, 1974. It was also not a bad year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were elected then, were you?

—That is right. As we all know, she served as a Cabinet Minister in this Government, first as Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women and, more recently, as Special Minister of State, with a range of responsibilities. I have had a lot of arguments with Susan Ryan over the period of our joint ministry-I think she will concede that-but they have never been conducted with any rancour. We have had differences--
—You pulled rank but not rancour.

—Mr President, this pre-Christmas wit is too much for me. I say very sincerely that those differences have always been conducted in a very friendly way. Sometimes they have been profound but they have always been like the brewery product-mild rather than bitter. I very much appreciate that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan has been a very talented, enthusiastic and committed Minister. The great philosopher, Herbert Spencer, once said, before he could have had the benefit of Susan Ryan's views on a number of issues-they were not available to Victorians-in what was a very sound injunction to Ministers:

The man of higher type must be content with greatly moderated expectations while he perseveres with undiminished efforts. He has to see how comparatively little can be done and yet find it worthwhile to do that little, so uniting philanthropic energy with philosophic calm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good heavens!

—I know it is a bit much for you, Senator, at this time of the year, but it is very important. In a sense it applies very much to the work which Susan has done as a Minister because, in many ways, she has been a pioneering figure in this place. Many of the things which women have achieved on the political agenda have been very much due to her efforts, and it has not been easy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan leaves the Senate in a very honourable way, that is, to take on a position as Publishing Editor of Penguin Books Australia Ltd-a great firm-to which she looks forward and in which position, I believe, she will acquit herself very well. She is not a politician leaving for retirement in terms of the best--

TALK.START.PARA: —A post overseas.

—Yes. Senator Lewis is completely locked into posts overseas. He has been offering me one for the past five years. I understand his anxiety to get rid of me. Senator Ryan is going to a position in which she will acquit herself well. I think it is a great thing for politicians that she is doing so. I think she will be very successful in that career.

SPEECH.PARA: She will have pleasant and unpleasant memories of this place. I hope that she will be sustained by the unpleasant memories because they will confirm her view that she made a very right decision to leave politics and to take on a job in the private sector, which I have come to admire more and more since I have been a politician. There are some things which she will leave behind her. As an avid reader of Penguin books, I hope that she will leave the National Agenda for Women behind her in politics and not intrude it into the publication of Penguins too much. I like a lot of books that Penguin publishes, Susan, and I could not really read all the books that might be on the women's agenda, or approved by the women's agenda. Still, as long as Penguin can publish Peter Corris and people like that I will be satisfied.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Allen and Unwin.

—But under the new regime at Penguin, Senator Ryan may well be able to get hold of Peter Corris. I hope that she can, because he will sell much more widely than he does at the moment for Allen and Unwin. On behalf of my Senate colleagues, I would like to wish Susan every success in her new career. In spite of all the exchanges that take place across this chamber, it has been a pleasure to have Susan Ryan as a senator. I think that all senators would agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity also of wishing every senator a successful Christmas and new year. My observation is that the Opposition is looking very tired. I recommend that they all take a good break, have a good rest and come back invigorated. People say that one gets better governments out of better oppositions. I concede that we can be better. If Opposition senators have a good rest, they may be better next year. I send those good wishes to all senators on both sides of the chamber.

I would like to thank the Clerks, staff and others. Mr President, I thank you for your sensible presiding over this chamber during the year. I hope that we can all look forward to a profitable, sensible year in 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, on behalf of the Opposition I extend my thanks to you, to the Clerks of the Senate and to the hundreds of people who help us during the year. It has been a very eventful year which turned out the wrong way for us, of course, in that it was an election year-an election that we lost. Senator Button is quite right: the Opposition is tired. It is thoroughly tired of being in opposition. We undertake to come back determined to take government again.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as extending our thanks to the many people who have added to our comfort, I too echo the sentiments of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, because I think that the Whips have done us proud during this session. I thank them for that because I believe it helps us greatly in the conduct of business in this place.

I have been wondering what I should say about Senator Ryan. I thought I would resist imitating Senator Button when he farewelled Opposition senators and said how sad it was to lose them because such rubbish was left behind. I will not say that to Senator Ryan on this occasion, true as it might be. Senator Ryan is leaving in a way which many of us might envy. She is going to another career which is peculiarly suited to her talents. For many years now I have said that Senator Ryan's talents lay in Australian literature. I want to thank her for proving that on this rare occasion I have had some prescience.

I recall a long plane journey from Kununurra to Perth when she was stranded by a strike during her period as shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I am always peculiarly cheerful when Labor senators and members are stranded by strikes. There seems to be a certain sort of justice in it. On this occasion, since Senator Ryan was anxious to get back to her family-I think she pulled that trick; she wanted desperately to get back to Canberra to feed her daughter-we flew together on a Royal Australian Air Force plane from Kununurra to Perth. I would like to be able to say that we talked of Australian literature. I think it would be more accurate to say that she talked of Australian literature and I listened. I am quite used to doing that. My spouse follows a similar role. I was very impressed, and have remained impressed, by her depth of knowledge and love of Australian literature. I think that it is a very good thing to have as a publisher at Penguin Books someone with those attributes. I wish her well. I am sure that all Opposition senators will wish her well in what I think will be a most interesting, useful and comparatively very pleasant career.

I do not intend at this stage to discuss Senator Ryan's politics. As I think back on her role as shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and shadow Minister for Education, I think I could probably enter into a debate with her right now on issues which were dearest to her heart and which were dear to mine and on which at times we held very contrary views. She has been a very pleasant person to have on the other side of the chamber. We will miss her but we certainly wish her well in her new career and life.

Mr President, it has been a long year and I think you have shown great patience and forbearance with us and the fairness that we sought of you when you were elected President. I particularly thank you for that. I hope that all honourable senators will have a Christmas which will touch their lives in a way which will mean that all Government senators will come back converted to the truth and that all Opposition senators will come back determined to ram the truth down their throats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of my Party and particularly Senator Haines, who had an engagement and had to catch a plane, I also would like to say that we will miss Senator Ryan. I think she probably stands out as a Minister mainly in terms of her role as Minister for Education, a portfolio which she held for so long. SPEECH.PARA: We in this place all too often take for granted the many people who support us over the year. I also thank the Clerks, who give unstintingly of their time and their advice. I thank the Hansard staff, who make our speeches into English that presumably at some stage will be tendered as scripts to Susan Ryan under the door in the hope of publication. I thank the dining room staff, the general Senate staff and the transport staff. Another group of people who do not appear here but who suffer constantly from what goes on in this chamber are our families. They know very well the types of things that probably a lot of people in the community do not understand, and that is the types of sacrifices that spouses and children make so that their father, mother or spouse is able to take part in public life.

We were very happy a couple of days ago to find out that the President was still the President a la the High Court of Australia judgment. For that all senators are all very much grateful as I am sure many other people here are. The election in the middle of the year significantly changed the composition of the chamber. I congratulate my new colleagues. It is remarkable how all the new senators quickly took to their role and managed to find their feet and engage in fairly rigorous debate-some more rigorous than others. A sort of sumo wrestler comes to mind, but I will not mention who that is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robert Ray has been in the House for years.

—I am sure all senators are very much looking forward to the bicentennial event that has been promised to us by two honourable senators. In closing, I wish all honourable senators a happy and holy Christmas. Hopefully, they will be able to partake of this period with their families and to enjoy some of the things that are denied for so long because of the contribution that all senators and all parties make to public life and to the governments of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

SPEECH.PARA: I want briefly just to say that, as well as being a person of ideas, you have seen the importance of establishing the processes, the structures and the administration necessary to make sure that those things that have been put in place stay there. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President and my Senate colleagues, I am a very fortunate person. Many Australians, I think most, form ideas about their society and aspirations about how they would like to see it improve and have ideals they would like to see implemented. It was a controversial move at the time, and I suppose controversy has dogged me ever since. Then there were the electors of the ACT, represented now by Margaret Reid and myself, who voted me into power and continued to do so over six elections. I am grateful to my Caucus colleagues who very early on gave me the opportunity to be the first woman to serve on a Labor front bench and therefore to get involved in the development of policies we would later implement. SPEECH.PARA: I would not have been able to achieve what I believe I have achieved had it not been for the excellent personal staff I have always been lucky enough to attract, and I would like to place on record my gratitude to them. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures are in place by the Federal Government in conjunction with State Administrations to monitor the following:
(a) recruitment of staff into the tourism and hospitality industry
(b) training of staff to take up suitable positions in these areas
(c) the monitoring of the payment of award wages, conditions and all other entitlements to employees in the industry.
(2) In an obviously expanding industry, how does the Australian performance in the service industry measure up to the demands of overseas consumers.
(3) What effects would there be on this level of service if penalty rates and holiday benefits be withdrawn to existing or potential employees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. (a) Recruitment of staff is facilitated and monitored through agencies of the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training such as the Hospitality Staffing Service (within the Commonwealth Employment Service) which provides specialised placements for the industry. Regular reports of Notification of Vacancies and other labour market data are provided to government and industry bodies to assist planning.
(b) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) compiles statistics on employment in a number of sectors of the hospitality industry, which are used by both Commonwealth and State Departments.

Measures to co-ordinate training of staff exist through the industry training network. The National Tourism Industry Training Committee is a tri-partite body (including representation from this portfolio) which oversights the activities of State industry training committees involving State government representation. There are also consultative mechanisms of education authorities (eg TAFE Hospitality Educators).
In a general context consultations with States on the matters covered by (a) and (b) are conducted primarily through the Australian Standing Committee on Tourism (ASCOT).

(c) The Arbitration Inspectorate, established within the Department of Industrial Relations, provides a labour inspection service, the primary function of which is to secure the observance of Federal awards. Such awards include a number which regulate the pay and conditions of employees in the tourism and, particularly, the hospitality areas. In pursuing this function, the Inspectorate responds to enquiries and complaints, conducts inspections of employment records and workplaces, seeks to have award breaches rectified voluntarily and, where necessary, institutes legal proceedings. The States and Territories also have labour inspection services to secure the observance of State/Territory industrial legislation, awards and determinations which, within jurisdiction, also regulate the pay and conditions of many employees within the tourism and hospitality areas. Whilst there are no formal arrangements in place to co-ordinate the activities of the various inspectorates, they maintain a close working relationship on matters of mutual concern. Additionally, of course, trade unions monitor the observance of award conditions in all jurisdictions.

(2) There have been no detailed formal studies comparing the Australian service industry to those overseas. However there is little doubt that with the recent increase in investment in tourism facilities, Australian hotels and resorts are now world class. Informal surveys undertaken by independent agencies have ranked Australian establishments among the top ten. Standards of service are more difficult to assess. However, the Australian Tourist Commission conducted a survey of tourists leaving Australia throughout 1986, seeking their impressions of particular aspects of their experiences. The results of this survey when available, should provide a good indicator of how well Australian standards of service satisfy demands.

(3) The Government is aware that penalty rates and holiday benefits such as annual leave loading are sometimes criticised as an obstacle to the provision of services in the tourism and hospitality sector. However, detailed studies into the effect of penalty rates on employment have not been conclusive in establishing such a relationship. In particular, studies by the National Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders University and the Monash University Centre of Policy Studies have concluded that, in the absence of penalty rates, additional compensation for work in non-standard hours may be necessary in order that sufficient supplies of adequately skilled employees are available at such times.

Any moves to alter longstanding employment conditions would need to have regard to the wider implications for the wage system and union commitment to that system. Under the Restructuring and Efficiency Principle within the current two-tier wage fixation system, however, there is opportunity for employers and unions to negotiate improved wages and employment conditions in exchange for greater efficiency, with the reform of restrictive and outmoded practices and award provisions. That is an avenue through which the industrial parties could address any existing arrangements considered to limit the efficiency of operation of the tourism and hospitality industry.
