QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 29 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In 1985, did the Department of Aviation (as it was then known) seek an audiogram test report from Mr Ben Buckley, a commercial pilot from Victoria, without specifying when this was to be carried out.
(2) Did the Department fail to reply to Mr Buckley when he wrote in late 1985 to ask if the test could wait until his routine annual medical check.
(3) When Mr Buckley sent his licence for routine annual stamping, did the Department withhold the licence.

(4) Did the Department continue to withhold the licence after three separate copies of the positive audiogram result had been forwarded and acknowledgment of receipt of the third of these was sent to Mr Buckley.
(5) Did the Department receive the second copy of the audiogram test result which included a note from Mr Buckley; and did a Department official later produce that note.

(6) Did the Department suspend Mr Buckley's licence in February this year and cancel it in April, giving as its reasons a contravention of Air Navigation Regulations (by flying without a licence), failure to fly an aircraft safely and that Mr Buckley was ``not a fit and proper person'' to hold a licence.
(7) Can the Department elaborate on these reasons as follows:
(a) other than flying without a licence while the Department was withholding it, when did Mr Buckley contravene Air Navigation Regulations;

(b) other than several instances of technical illegality in which Mr Buckley was flying badly injured children to hospital, can the Department say when Mr Buckley failed in his duty to fly an aircraft safely;
(c) on what basis does the Department consider Mr Buckley ``not a fit and proper person'' to hold a licence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 18 October 1985 Mr Buckley was advised that an audiogram was required in connection with the medical examination he had recently undertaken for the renewal of his licence. Because of his age this was the first year that Mr Buckley had been required to have an audiogram and his licence had been renewed in anticipation that he would quickly meet that requirement. In the event he did not do so until February 1987.

(2) No. The Department wrote to Mr Buckley about the need for an audiogram on 18 October and again on 19 November 1985. In response to his letter of 9 December 1985 the Department asked him on 18 December 1985 to arrange a test within three months. Mr Buckley agreed to this in a further letter of 13 February 1986 but did not comply, although he again wrote on 9 April 1986 requesting that it be deferred until his September 1986 medical examination. This was not agreed to but his licence was allowed to run its normal course.

(3) Mr Buckley's licence expired on 30 September 1986 and was received for annual renewal on that date. This is not merely a routine stamping. As Mr Buckley had not fulfilled the medical requirements in regard to an audiogram and eye examination his licence could not be renewed. He was reminded by letters dated 26 October 1986 and 11 November 1986 that he had not yet met the medical requirements for renewal of his Commercial Pilot Licence. Considerable effort was made to contact Mr Buckley by telephone and in early January 1987 he advised that he had undertaken and passed an audiogram some six weeks previously. Again Departmental officers expended considerable effort in trying to contact the person who had conducted the audiogram in an endeavour to expedite renewal of the licence. Efforts up to and including 29 January 1987 were not successful in obtaining a copy of the audiogram.

(4) No. Records show that only two copies of Mr Buckley's audiogram were received by the Department. The first of these was received on 10 February 1987, four months after his licence had expired and 16 months after the audiogram originally became due. The name on the form was ``Ben'' Buckley and was not immediately identified with Pearce Edward Buckley. It is relevant to note in this context that some 700 medical reports are received each week and there are 57 pilots named ``Buckley'' currently on file. The Director of Aviation Medicine issued a ``pass'' assessment in respect of Buckley's medical on 9 March 1987. A second copy of Mr Buckley's audiogram was received in the Department on 10 March 1987 from his solicitors under cover of a letter dated 6 March 1987.

(5) The first copy of Mr Buckley's audiogram which was received by the Department on 10 February 1987 included a note from Mr Buckley. This note was provided to Mr Buckley and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) as part of the documents required to be lodged under Section 37 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

(6) No. Mr Buckley's licence was suspended on 27 April 1987 and cancelled on 16 June 1987. The full reasons for the cancellation are contained in the cancellation letter sent to Mr Buckley on 16 June 1987. If Mr Buckley has no objection I can make a copy of the letter available to the honourable Senator.

(7) The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 provides a right of appeal to the AAT against licence cancellation. Mr Buckley appealed to the AAT and also requested an order temporarily ``staying'' the Secretary's action. The ``stay'' application was dealt with on 13-14 August 1987 and refused. The Tribunal stated that ``it would not be proper to grant a stay in this case as the risk is too great''. The full appeal has yet to be heard. But for an adjournment sought by the applicant this matter would have been heard on 30 November 1987. The other questions raised by the honourable Senator have still to be dealt with by the Tribunal and it would not be appropriate for me to comment on them at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 2 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Was the predicted saving in outlays of $12.6 million for 1986-87 referred to in the Second Reading Speech for the Superannuation and Other Benefits Amendment Bill 1986 achieved; if not, what was the actual result.

(2) Is it correct that some 113,000 beneficiaries were adversely affected by the 2 per cent discounting authorised by the Superannuation and Other Benefits Amendment Act 1986 effective from 10 October 1986; if so, (a) what percentage of those beneficiaries received offsetting adjustments under Social Security legislation from 10 October 1986 in the following categories: (i) Defence Force Retirement Benefits, (ii) Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits, (iii) Superannuation Act 1922, (iv) Superannuation Act 1976, (v) Papua-New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) Legislation; and (b) what was the cost involved in each case.

(3) Is it correct that the anticipated savings in outlays of $12.6 million referred to in the Second Reading Speech for the Superannuation and Other Benefits Act 1986 was a gross figure; if so, will the Minister for Finance provide the offsetting amounts for 1986/87 for short falls in income tax revenue and medicare levy due to the 2 per cent discounting under that Act.

(4) Is it correct that: (a) prior to 1948 members of the Defence Forces contributed to benefits under the occupational superannuation provisions of the Superannuation Act 1922; and (b) a large number of veterans from World War I, World War II, Korea and Vietnam have been contributors under the Superannuation Act 1922 and 1976; if so, will the Minister for Finance provide an estimate of the relevant number of beneficiaries under those acts in comparison with some 32,800 beneficiaries under the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits and Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Acts.
(5) How many veterans or their dependants are included in some 650 beneficiaries at 30 June 1986 under the Papua-New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Savings in outlays for 1986-87 (estimated in the Second Reading Speech for the Superannuation and Other Benefits Amendment Bill 1986 as $12.6m) is now estimated to have been $15 million.

2. Yes. As superannuation benefits are not subject to a means test the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office (AGRBO) does not hold information on what assets or income from other sources pensioners may be receiving or whether they are in receipt of Social Security benefits. It is therefore not possible to calculate the percentage of beneficiaries who received offsetting adjustments under Social Security legislation, or the costs sought. Tables I9-I12 of the Commissioner's Annual Report for 1985-86 provide a stratification of numbers of pensioners by levels of pension and show, for comparison purposes, the income means test cut-off points for various levels of Social Security Age Pension entitlement.
3. The $12.6 million predicted savings was a gross figure. Based on that figure, loss of income tax and medicare levy was estimated to be $2.8 million for 1986/87.
4. (a) This is partly correct. Prior to the implementation of the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948 the position was:
(i) Both officers and other ranks in the Permanent Military Forces contributed for benefits under the Superannuation Act 1922 and became eligible for full pension at age 60.

(ii) Airmen in the Permanent Air Force contributed for benefits under the Superannuation Act 1922. Officers were credited with deferred pay and they also contributed for restricted benefits, i.e. they had a cover against invalidity or death while serving but if a pension was payable under that provision no deferred pay was paid.

(iii) The pay rates of the Permanent Naval Forces consisted of active pay and deferred pay, the latter being credited because no superannuation provision was made for Permanent Naval personnel on retirement.

(b) As preference in recruitment was given to veterans under the Public Service Act a large number of veterans would have been contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. However, former members of the Defence Force are not separately identified in AGRBO's superannuation data and therefore the number of such veterans is not available.

5. Although some former members of the Defence Force or their dependants may be included amongst the beneficiaries under the Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) Scheme, they are not separately identified in AGRBO's records.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 December 1987 (Hansard, page 2892), Senator Michael Baume asked me a series of questions without notice about the impact of the stock market collapse on the performance of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) and the implications for the entitlements of contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS).

ANSWER.PARA: By way of background, I should explain that the retiring age benefits payable under the CSS are in two parts:
(a) a defined benefit in the form of an indexed non-commutable pension financed by the employer; and

(b) an employee-financed benefit that can be taken either as a non-indexed pension or as a lump sum equal to the aggregate of the employee's contributions accumulated with interest at rates prescribed by regulation from time to time.

The size of the employee-financed benefit is directly related to the performance of SFIT which is responsible for investing the contributions of members of the scheme. Clearly, however, the employer-financed pension is unaffected by the stock market crash. However, certain types of lump sum employer-financed benefits are related to the size of the accumulated contributions of members-as for example, retrenchment benefit where one option is a lump sum of 3 1/2 times accumulated basic contributions.
The following answers to Senator Baume's questions have been provided by the Acting Chairman of SFIT:

(a) Consistent with the experience of other large superannuation funds with investments in the sharemarket, the value of SFIT's share portfolio declined during October 1987. The extent of the decline in the equities portfolio as at 28 October was approximately $300 million as reported in the notes to the 1986-87 financial statements.

(b) At 30 November 1987 (latest available figures), SFIT's domestic and overseas equities portfolio (representing approximately 30% of the total fund) had incurred a ``loss'' of approximately $355 million since 30 June 1987. Of this total, approximately $280 million relates to the domestic equities portfolio and $75 million to the offshore portfolio.

(c) The unrealised loss on SFIT's holding in the Bell Group of Companies (Bell Group Ltd, JN Taylor Holdings Ltd and Bell Resources Ltd) at 30 November 1987 was approximately $86m from the value of SFIT's holding in that stock at 30 June 1987. Other institutions with the same or larger holdings in these stocks would have incurred similar losses on their holdings.

(d) Any individual or funds manager with a share portfolio would have been affected by the stock market slump, just as they would have benefited from the earlier boom in stock market prices. Over the longer term, however, empirical evidence shows that investments in shares outperform non-equity investments. Given the long term nature of superannuation funds management, prudence demands that share investments should continue to feature in SFIT's portfolio notwithstanding the recent slump.

(e) At 30 June 1987, SFIT held 23% of its portfolio (or approximately $1100 million) in the domestic share market and 8.4% (or approximately $376 million) in overseas markets (mostly shares). As at 30 November these proportions were approximately 20.9% and 8.9% respectively. Given SFIT's modest exposure to international equities markets and the fact that the decline in the value of Australian shares was greater than that of overseas markets and decline in the domestic market had the greater effect on SFIT's portfolio. In other words, had SFIT been more heavily weighted in international markets the effect on SFIT's equities portfolio overall would have been less. Nevertheless, SFIT's exposure to equities generally was well below that of many other funds some of whom had equity exposures in excess of 50% of their portfolios.

(f) The impact on contributors in the short term is that the ``exit'' allocation rate which, as the term implies, applies to contributors leaving the CSS, has been set at zero percent until such time as SFIT's performance warrants a review of that rate. Contributors staying in the scheme will not have the exit rate applied to them-they will bear their share of the share market losses when the allocation rate for the financial year 1987-88 is later declared. That rate will be based on SFIT's overall performance for 1987-88, after taking into account the extraordinary losses in October 1987. In that context SFIT is targeting a positive performance rate, albeit single digit, for 1987-88.

(g) After an exhaustive inquiry into the operations of SFIT, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in 1985 unanimously recommended that market value of accounting be adopted for the Fund (this supported an earlier decision by SFIT to move to market value accounting). Accordingly, the CSS allocation policy is based on the allocation of both realised and unrealised gains and losses. The $791.8 million is allocated by application of the 1986-87 annual interest rate, whereas any gains or losses attributable to the current financial year will be reflected in the annual allocation rate set for that year. As I mentioned earlier, SFIT is targeting a positive performance rate for 1987-88.
It should not be overlooked that contributors have benefited considerably from attractive performance rates achieved by SFIT which have averaged 20% per annum compound over the past four years.

The $791.8m referred to in answer (g) above is, I am advised, the amount available for allocation to contributors from the 1986-87 income, and this allocation is unaffected by the subsequent fall in the stock market.

I can only add to that response from the Acting Chairman by emphasising that the Fund comprises the contributions of members of the scheme and income earned thereon; there are no employer moneys in the Fund. Moreover, as a result of the attractive performance rates mentioned by the Acting Chairman, the annual allocation rates have averaged 17 per cent per annum over the past 4 years, after the application of a smoothing process. As stated in my Press release dated 27 November 1987, the performance will be closely monitored and the exit rate revised as soon as positive returns are achieved.
